description:
This place is delicious.. everything is good that I have had the falafel yum.. the taboli salad delicious.
Lamb Sharma amazing.....
I always spend to much money when I go here. I want everything.  Everyone that works there is friendly.
author: Christophe T.

description: The food was just good but overpriced for what it was. They up-charge for every little modification or replacement that you make. And the service was pretty terrible.
author: K One P.

description: It used to be reasonably priced but now is very expensive - 9 dollars for one pint of hummus.  Also very unfriendly service - the man behind the counter seemed to be doing us a favor by serving us.  Would like to find a reasonably priced Middle Eastern deli in Bay Area - maybe Whole Foods or Trader Joe's is only option,
author: Dan L.

description:
Sunrise Deli in San Francisco is a tiny hole-in-the-wall looking type of restaurant and it tastes like one too! Went there and ordered 3 Falafels which I think were decent for the price. The ambient inside is not dine-in friendly since there are very few chairs, and if you want a bathroom you need to walk through the kitchen. The bathroom is tiny, and feels like it shouldn't be for customers, but the restaurant made up for it because the hummus, falafel, and meat were delicious! All at a great price point too! 

Will definitely be going back when I am in SF again! 

Happy dining 
Omar
author: Omar C.

description: I've been eating fast food all week, been craving for a good home cooked meal, found this place, my favorite was chicken kabob w/rise and lentils side of cucumber/tomato salad and pita bread. Just like home made can't wait for my next visit.
author: Sammy D.

description:
For years, my Dad would always buy me falafels from this little shop and they've always been my favorite. 

I recently came back from Israel and I've been craving middle eastern food so much. I've tried so many other falafel places in SF and while many were very good, this place still tastes like the ones I had in the holy land. The owner is super nice and the food tastes authentic and delicious! Plus they have Turkish delights ;)
author: Margaret K.

description: If you are Arabic or Lebonese you will love this place reminds me of my hometown Lebanon number one place to come and eat me and my family were looking around to get something to eat my wife found this place I recommend it highly recommend it very nice people services greatBest falafel in town
author: Ali G.

description: Best Falfael and swarma in town.  Authentic vibes and friendly service.  Supreme deserts, try the Turkish delight.  Only challenge is parking.
author: Eric A.

description:
The falafels are great, but the rest of what we tried wasn't very good. However, I did just come back from a trip to Israel, and it's really hard to find comparable hummus and schwarma here. My friends and I came around noon on a Sunday, and it was busy with a lot of people coming in and out. It took them about 10 minutes to make our order, and we tried:

-Lamb Schwarma on a Plate w/Hummus (Large /$12): The schwarma was too salty, and I didn't like the spices. The hummus was also disappointing, and wasn't very smooth. I wouldn't get this again.
-Avocado Falafel (Falafel w/Avocado, Hummus, Lettuce, Tomato, Pickled Cabbage, Served in a Pita Pocket, $7.50, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=_w84QAnwHJdM2nXVGIGEXg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The falafel was really good, and I loved the crispy exterior and fluffy interior. However, the rest of the pita was really uninspiring- the pita was not warm and fluffy, and the rest of the ingredients were just there, and didn't add anything flavor wise. Skip the pita pocket and just order the falafel separately.

The people working here were really nice and friendly, so I feel bad giving a low rating, but I wouldn't return based on my experience here. However, their falafel is good, so I'd definitely recommend coming here if you like falafel! Parking in this area is always tough, especially during the busy weekends, but street parking is available.
author: Amy D.

description: When the sign reads "Best Falafel in Town", Believe It. I'll always appreciate small businesses staying alive and giving the locals what they want. MORE FALAFEL!!
author: Tatianni D.

description:
Sunrise Deli is somewhat of an icon in San Francisco. Among the countless Asian grocery stores and eateries on Irving St sits this inconspicuous falafel joint with schwarmas rotating at the window. Because my Asian parents frequented Irving St for groceries, Sunrise was actually the first place I had Mediterranean food as a kid, and I finally got to return after so many years!

This is definitely a hole-in-the wall with limited seating and perhaps not the nicest atmosphere (there are clouds of fryer smoke polluting the dining room). I ordered the large vegetarian plate, which came with Greek salad and tabbouleh (both very lemony), hummus and baba ghanoush (a little watery and indistinct in flavor), mujadara (lentils, rice, fried onions), dolmas, and falafel (by far the best part of the platter). The falafel were crispy and flavorful without being greasy--you could tell these were very fresh! However, nothing else about the platter was particularly memorable--next time, I might just stick to the one thing they're known for!
author: David K.

description:
This is where one comes for good, wholesome falafels! 

Have a falafel sandwich with tahini or the cucumber yogurt, it's the best! It's also awesome to get platter's done with a dozen falafel, baba ghanoush, hummus, cucumber yogurt and pita. Always feels like being back in the Middle East.

At times, we buy a pint or two of just the falafel dough and make it at home. It's almost just as good as having it piping hot from the shop.
author: Hala A.

description: Extremely dissatisfied I ordered the Shawarma plate to go then the meat was cold. Pita was cold...almost no food for $17.00 WTF. I was hoping some of the reviews might be misleading..what a disappointmen
author: Dee D.

description:
Ordered for office through Caviar.

Ten shawarmas and two falafel pitas. Menus says they should all have hummus, either they forgot or they spread a small dollop on the shawarmas. The wraps were stuffed with way too many onions, pickled veggies and lettuce. The lamb and chicken portion was okay. Many on our staff ate half and tossed the rest. 

Falafel was good, flavorful and soft
Hummus was okay
Pita chips were the biggest hit... fried pita, who knew!
author: Eddy L.

description: Food is good but the owner is a greedy and unfriendly guy. Not coming back here again and have been going for many years.  I don't eat tomatoes and asked if I can get one piece of dolma instead...  it really shouldn't have been a problem. Anyway he was rude to me and seemed to not care about customers. Then he charged me an extra 10$ by "accident " on my card and removed the charge. Bye !!!!!
author: Monica P.

description:
In the area getting the Mr's iPhone repaired & saw Sunrise Deli - which was very fortuitous since we were planning on bringing falafels into our movie

I've visited the location near my work so knew this would be a great choice

Super Falafel Wraps - had humus, eggplant, potatoes, lettuce & falafels

Lovely depth of flavor & hit the spot
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Expensive for the quality and quantity. The shwarma wrap was very thin, and small shwarma plate was very small. Each of them were $9.

Dry, tough meat and not much of it. It was pretty flavorless too. The turnip pickles were definitely from a can (they are super easy to make). The pita was very thin and dry (crackly too). 

I also didn't feel so good the next morning. 

The people behind the counter were very nice though.
author: L Z.

description: The vegan Avocado falafel wrap was out of this world! No, out of this universe...no outta this dimension! :) Their baklava was fresh and tasty too! Service is friendly and efficient, I immensely recommend for an authentic Middle Eastern meal.
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description: They made me an edible Chicken Shawarma Late night! Came in clutch! Nice staff. I'd recommend it late at night when all the shawarma stops are closed!
author: Mahmoud A.

description:
Paid $9 for a shawerma plate, you'd think for that price you'd get something decent, however the plate that came was so tiny, just a bit of hummus and a bit of shawerma and tomato on top of that, it tasted okay but wasn't amazing. My friend got a dish with rice in it and we saw the guy put the rice that had been sitting there all day probably in the microwave to heat it up! The worker was nice enough though, he was polite. 

Basically one star off for the tiny overpriced portions and a star off for the mediocre taste and the microwaving of the rice. 

The only thing you should get from here is the falafel, that stuff was amazing! It was priced well and was fresh and tasty. I'd give 5 stars for the falafel if I wasn't so disappointed by everything else. If I ever come here again I'm definitely getting the falafel and only that.
author: Abdurahman L.

description:
Sunrise Deli was an impromptu stop as i found an unexpired meter parking nearby. falafel is their game and i ordered lamb shawarma. what a mistake! It's the falafel, S.....! to paraphrase a political figure i no longer admire. there's no triangulating a menu when only one item (falafel) or two (baklava) is fab and the rest is thumbs down.

no spits seen which should have a headsup. a dozen falafel only 6, what a mistake in ordering!

eats: lamb shawarma (8)
-micro sized wrap, only a little bigger than wraps at Jack (yep, that clown)
-lamb cubes reminded me of kibbles without the moisture.
very little lettuce, tomato, hummus, onions,  pickled cabbage noticed in wrap.
*no leakage as no tsatziki sauce was used in the making of this shawarma.
-tasteless. lacking in veggies too.

take outs:
-shoulda gone with falafel, their game, 4 stars for sure.
-shawarmas should be made by artisans, not by eagle eyed shoppers via food warehouses.
-service polite, only one prep guy doing it all.
author: Victor G.

description:
Have been supporting this establishment for ages.   They are consistent with their great service, and even better food.  

I love their seating area - clean, super casual, but doesn't lack warm welcoming service.   Decent chilled drink selection in the back to go with your delicious food.   By this point I have tried everything on their menu, many of them more than once.   Hard to pick a favorite since everything is always fresh, tasty, and prepared well.  

And more times than not when we come here we take additional stuff to go because it's not easy to get tired of their great food.  With this type of food, I don't tend to feel gross afterwards like with some other cuisines.   

These guys do it right!  Thank you for many years of superb hospitality and countless honest meals!  See you soon...again.
author: Jamie S.

description:
This was the first time trying this place, and everything we had was pretty good.  We got the chicken and kufta kebab plates with hummus, babaganush, falafel, and dolmas as sides.  They also had kibbes on a plate and seemed a bit old and I asked the guy if they were fresh and he said yes, however they definitely were not and that the reason why I'm giving it 4 starts.  The kebabs and the falafels were made at the time of the order and were amazing, hopefully next time they'll have fresher kibbes or I definitely won't order them.

All in all its not bad for a quick lunch or to get some falafels to go.  Definitely some of the best falafels I had.

The sandwiches (pitas and laffas ) are reasonably priced and I will be back to try them since they looked pretty good.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
I was craving shawarma , so I popped into Sunrise to get my fix . I ordered the lamb pita shawarma .  This was by far the worst shawarma I've ever tasted . It consist of lamb bits , onions and some pickled vegetable . The pita was so saturated with the pickle juice: making it super soggy and too nasty to eat .  One bite was all I can handle . I had to cut my loses and went across the street for Banh Minh. 

Don't know how this place is still in business
author: Joe L.

description:
Came here after drooling over the photos of the shawarma plate all weekend. We ordered 2 dozen falafels but the generous owner/cook gave us more. I also ordered the large lamb/beef shawarma plate without pita bread. Yeah, I know what you're thinking: how can I not eat hummus and meat with pita bread?! Well, doctors orders...no carbs. :(

I wanted to save some for lunch tomorrow but my husband didn't have lunch today so I let him eat until he was content. We ordered a dozen more falafels and a small chicken shawarma plate to split for our lunch tomorrow.

Everything was really delicious and service was awesome. Would definitely come back!
author: V M.

description: My husband and I buy a dozen falafel a week, we love them so much! I am a big fan of their falafel wrap, and I used to eat their chicken kabob sandwich before I went vegetarian. Delicious!
author: A M.

description:
I was standing outside for a few minutes, trying to decide whether or not I should walk in when three people practically ran past me and into the establishment. Smart choice. 

After ordering, they make your food pretty quickly so you don't have to wait for a long time. There are plenty of seats if you'd like to sit down while waiting. I stared at the hummus because it was so beautiful while waiting for my order, but it's also nice to watch them make your order. 

Chicken kabob sandwich: 
This looks deceivingly small but they put a lot of ingredients into it. Unfortunately, the pita bread was a bit hard. Shouldn't pita bread be soft...? However, I appreciate how they actually put a lot of chicken in it unlike other places that put like three small pieces of chicken and call it a chicken kabob sandwich. Half of it was enough to fill me up. Eat this right when you get it before it cools down. 

Falafels: 
You have an option of buying half a dozen or one dozen. I recommend getting one dozen. It's more worth the money and it's so delicious, I couldn't stop eating it. They make it right after you order it, so they're extremely hot and fresh when they give it to you. 

Super Falafel:
Not bad, but I wish the lavish bread was softer. I wish I had requested the sandwich with pita bread instead, but oh well. The lavish bread was quite hard and cold. I saved this for later so I could add more hummus to it and microwave it, which made it taste so much better. I ate this with the fresh falafels that I had ordered...

The service was excellent and I really appreciate the customer service here. 

Honestly, I'd give this place maybe a 3/5 stars for the sandwiches but the falafels are easily worth way more than 5/5 stars. Come here for the falafels. I think I'm just super picky with the sandwiches but in my opinion, they taste a lot better if you add a lot of hummus to them, wrap them with softer and warmer pita bread, and heat them up.
author: Lawrence K.

description:
I give this place 4 or 5 stars for the falafel and 2-3 stars for everything else including the steamy interior. Their falafel are always fresh and tasty. 

It's located conveniently next to one of the good grocery stores in the sunset area which makes buying groceries and fresh falafel a great combo for a middle eastern Sunday breakfast.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
Oh my, Sunrise Deli....I'm so sorry I lost touch with you! I used to come here after school to get falafels as snacks, but haven't been back since graduating (literally, circa 2008). 

I opted for a half dozen falafels which came straight out of the fryer. They were hot, crispy, and super flavorful and a pretty great deal at $4.35 (with tax). They are also bigger than most other falafel/Mediterranean places. My only gripe was definitely how oily they were. I actually would have loved to had accompany my falafels with some tahini or the yogurt/cucumber dip but their minimum quantity was a half pint, which was excessive for my needs and not conducive to surviving safely in a backpack - perhaps when I'm not foot traveling though!

I'll definitely be back.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Meh. They were out of lamb. The chicken shawarma was OK. I felt the marinade or whatever they did to the chicken was too strongly acidic, like they added too much lemon juice. The pita to filling ratio was pretty low. The pita itself was dry. I think it comes from a bag, definitely not freshly made. This sounds very negative, but it was still pretty good, just because shawarma is hard to mess up. 

The falafel and sauce they have for it is impeccable. The man at the front was very friendly.
author: jones z.

description:
Ironically, it was Yelp that brought me to this location, so I thought I'd give it a shot. Given I had not previously tried Falafel, this seemed like a great spot for my first time.

I was right! The Falafel sandwich was delicious. Portions were just right, the sauce complimented it perfectly, every bite was joyful. I've clearly been missing out on this delicious brand of cuisine.

The young lady who attended me was quite kind. I mentioned it was my first time visiting this location, as well as having Falafel, and she gave me a brief history lesson on the location, including a recommendation for my next visit. 
No complaints on my end, everything was great and I'll definitely be stopping by here on my next visit to the city!
author: Alex S.

description: the pickled turnips were moldy.  the dolmas were expensive and the lamb was tough.
author: Margaret D.

description: Best falafel in the city. Crispy crunchy spicy light and fluffy falafs. Om nom nom. Super local location that's been around for decades. Interior is a workspace so don't bring your snobby transplant friends. Protip, buy a dozen falafels and then go next door and get pita bread and veggies for a GGP picnic.
author: Robert W.

description:
My dad is a super unadventurous eater, but my sister and I were able to cajole him to join us for dinner at Sunrise Deli. His verdict -- A-OK! (Which is high praise from him).

Rating Breakdown --

1/2 Stars for Taste:
If this review was just for falafels, this would be 3/2 stars. The falafels are so crispy and flavorful, I could easily eat half a dozen by myself (which, to my shame, I have done before). However, I found the kebab options kind of underwhelming. The chicken was dry, the baba ganoush was nothing to write home about, the cucumber yogurt salad was bland. 

The dessert options were on the side of sickly sweet, but then again, baklava and Turkish delights are literally just sugar on sugar.

1/1 Stars for Value:
You can easily stuff yourself for less than $10 at Sunrise Deli. I personally like to drop by for some piping hot falafels -- I think it's $4 for 6 and $6 for 12.

1/1 Stars for Customer Service:
Super simple set-up inside, I think most people order to-go. Once, when dining in, we ordered a dozen falafels and the woman behind the counter hooked it up with an extra falafel and free sauces (hummus and tzaziki). When ordering out falafels, they often throw in a free sauce as well. 

Bonus star because this is my go-to place when I'm craving something deep fried but don't want to feel too guilty about it afterwards.
author: Abby W.

description: Best falafel in town no lie and I'll tell you why. Crispy outside, moist and soft inside, pop of flavor from solid base and spices/herbs used, and fresh because they constantly make falafel. That is the star of this restaurant but for meat eaters  kibbeh and kufta are my go to. I recommend trying the dips and salads see if they adhere to your taste. Pretty standard recipes they do. A nice addition to make a nourishing meal. I like spicy food so I always like some home made shata, a middle eastern hot sauce. Finally, dessert can be classic baklava or their no added sugar date cookie! So good with a little less guilt. They also make s cookie or gharaba that delicately  melts in your mouth.
author: Lara H.

description: Is this under new ownership? Falafel sandwich came on two halves of a pita (usually one large one), and the falafel were quite spicy. Different than they used to be, unless it was a bad batch...
author: minj b.

description:
Always busy. Great fresh food always cooked to order. Very casual dining. 
I'm a huge fan of the falafel wraps but have tried several other dishes on the menu. I have never been disappointed with anything. 
Either sit in or to go orders the staff is very efficient and friendly. 
The price is between $4-9 for almost everything on the menu. 
Street parking only.
author: Frances L.

description:
A quick personal background note that is relevant to my otherwise "brief" review.  I used to live in the Middle East and had eaten falafel on MANY occasions.  Further, I gave up gluten (glue-ten, that comes from wheat flour 18 years ago (before it became more "trendy").  So, no more pita, no more baklava for me.   :- (

I had been going to Sunrise for one particular item, their halvah.  When the halvah is fresh(er), it is EXCELLENT.  No, not all halvah is created equal (unlike people, right?).

So I was there a week or so ago to buy a small slab of their fresh halvah (with pistachios, nearly a must) and I had a hankering for a few falafel balls.  I bought two to go, ate them straight up (why not?!).  They were ABSOLUTELY The Best I have ever had; lighter than pillows, yet had that necessary outer crunch.  Not gooey nor heavy in the middle.  I was surprisingly impressed with them.  Like all things deep fried, they must be eaten within a short time of being extracted from the fryer.

So, take yourself over to Sunrise Deli, talk with the nice folks there, and try some of their tasty food.  And fresh is ALWAYS better!

I only gave 4 of 5 stars as I cannot speak for many of their foods (especially anything with gluten in it).
author: Ted N.

description:
Ordered for catering for a a meeting - two platters and desserts. Everything was devoured and everyone said how delicious it all was. Very happy with the quality of food, the presentation, and the price. 
Thank you - will be back again for sure!
author: Caroline P.

description: These guys make the BEST falafel I've ever had. The place is so cool and so friendly. I live in Petaluma, and make it a point to stop by when I'm in the city. I buy a dozen to go, for $8.00,  and make all kinds of dishes with it at home. The guys that run it are mellow and actually have a sense of humor. 500 STARS.
author: Sheldon B.

description:
I had very, very high hopes for this place. However, the food quality was just not up to par and not very worth the price. I would only come back for the falafels. 

I've tried both the lamb and chicken, and both were very dry :( especially the lamb.. it was very chewy and lacking in flavor. 

The falafels were pretty good. They have a great crunchy coating with a moist center. Honestly, not sure about the whole 'best falafel in town' thing, but they were pretty damn good. 

Service was okay though quite slow (even though we were the only customers there). Overall environment feels dated and not very welcoming. Better for grab&go.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Sunrise!! Why are you resting so hard on your laurels? Don't rest too long or risk losing all your stars and some customers. 

Last time I came the guys working were very sloppy with our food preparation. 

The lamb tasted foul and old. Didn't eat it. 

The lavash was stale. 

The falafel (my favorite) was not good. You know why? Cause you stopped making them fresh! I don't want leftover falafel you fried an hour ago for somebody else. I'm paying for fresh falafel. Please provide it. 

Sunrise, I used to really love you but you've put a rotten taste in my mouth. Please replace that rotten taste with fresh, hot falafel balls. Otherwise this will be the end of our relationship. **Fair warning**
author: Rosalyn W.

description: My local spot. Perfect falafel. I get the veggie combo. I swap out the dolmas for two more falafel and the rice for the cucumber yogurt. They sell pita bread and falafel by the dozen.  Great for lunch picnics. Vegetarian friendly. I sometimes party on the avocado falafel. Falafel is hard to stop eating especially here. I probably could eat over a dozen with a nice half pint of baba. Their hot sauce is very mellow but tasty.
author: Johnny B.

description:
I really like Sunrise Deli. I have done many take outs for two and for smaller impromptu dinner parties--friends love it.  They will cook falafels fresh right there for you so they are piping hot. The chicken kabob is a hit with guests. The sides and salads are good. We usually get the tabouli salad, hummus, dolmas, and sometimes the lentil rice. They also have a good selection of pastries and desserts. 
I call ahead for pick up, especially if I want to order lots and it's always ready.  They are quick and super friendly.
author: Shelley P.

description:
My company was having a Holiday party and we needed party trays. I have contacted several restaurants/companies that does catering or party trays and I decided to go for Sunrise Deli.

The workers here were friendly and responsive whenever I called. I called this location and asked what they recommended and how much food I should order. They recommended me to get a couple of veggie platters, kabobs, shwarmas, and falafel. I told them my budget and the total was less than I thought it would be and we even had food leftover!

The food was so delicious especially the falafels. It was one of the best falafels I ever had. The dolmas were soft and flavorful.It was my first time trying dolmas and I was not disappointed. The kabobs and shwarmas were not dry and it was grilled well and tender. Many people seemed to be enjoying the food very much as well!

I would definitely come back for party trays since the workers are accommodating and can't wait to stop by for lunch next time I am in the area.
author: Allie Y.

description: Without question some of the best falafel I've had in the city.  Perfectly light and crispy outside, with a moist flavorful center.  At only $.50 a piece if you get a dozen they're a staggeringly good deal.
author: Joshua W.

description: Love this place. Closest falafel I've had to Israel and West Bank. It's places like this that make me love San Francisco.
author: Stanley B.

description:
THE BEST FALAFEL/WRAP IVE EVER HAD. I came here with my bf and we split a chicken shawarma plate and a falafel wrap.

The shawarma plate was delicious and came with a flavorful and tangy hummus. It also came with pita bread to eat it with. The falafel wrap was the best mediterranean wrap I've ever had. And I've been to several mediterranean places in berkeley. This wrap also had eggplant and other vegetables inside and was amazing. The two items really hit the spot for me and my bf. Portion sizes were decent, and enough for the two of us.

Prices are cheap. Everything on the menu is great value. 

Service was timely and people were friendly. There is a great neighborhood restaurant feel and we never felt rushed or anything. 

Would definitely come here again!
author: Julie L.

description: This is a review that's long over due. I remembered being a recent San Jose transplant going to SF State and unfortunately I didn't have a whole lot of money. I was walking outside one day and just happen to walk by when one of the possible owners called me in, "Bro, have you ever been here before?" I've never had any middle eastern food, let alone shawarmas or falafels. I replied back with a "no" and he said, "grab a seat". He tells me to sit tight and that he would be back. Basket in hand with some fried dough looking thing and said, "This is gonna change your life bro, enjoy". I didn't have any money and he said, "Don't worry about it." I had a bite of my first falafel. It was life changing lol It opened me up to a whole new world of food, but also reminded me of how nice and kind people could be. This happened about 15 years ago, but I'll never forget that. I'm sure the food is good and hope that the same good people still work there. Whenever I'm up there next time, I hope to make it back.
author: John C.

description: The rumors are true...this just might be the best falafel in all of Sunset, if not the city. I prefer Taboun's hummus and veggie combo plate, but Sunrise Deli's falafel-based items are definitely way better. My husband is a huge fan of their super falafel sandwich, which has a great bread to filling ratio and is chalk full of veggies and their amazing falafel. Other pros is that they accept credit cards and seem to have a delectable array of sweets (e.g., baklava, Turkish delights, etc). I still haven't gotten a chance to try these yet and may have to upgrade my review if they are as good as they look!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Let's face it; the place is old, and the decor is dingy...

But what I want to tell you about is the food. The Kubeh is excellent, and I often walk a mile just to taste it. The food here is the real thing, so nevermind the decor. And the owner is an old soul, true and friendly. Sometimes there is a amazing music playing in the background... but the Kubeh! $3.26 for a wonderful Kubeh with some lettuce and humus to dip it in. Beats the $11.00 hamburgers in my neighborhood by a mile. Trust me, the food... the food. Get some!
author: Tarm Y.

description:
Came here today for some snacks, it was pretty dirty and dingy feeling inside. Which is fine, we ordered food to go, and sometimes the most unappealing hole-in-the-wall spots have the best food.

We ordered small sides of different things, like the cucumber yogurt salad, falafel, tomato cucumber salad, and dolmas.

Both the salads were very fresh tasting, though I prefer my cucumber yogurt salad with more tang. Sunrise Deli's tastes like it was mixed with sour cream or something more with a basic milk component. 

Falafel was decent, the outer layer was nice and crispy, but I wasn't really impressed by the inner texture. Dry, spongey and mealy, not in a good way. They were good to eat with the yogurt salad as a sort of dipping sauce.

I'd say my least favorite of the sides we got were the dolmas. Not sure if they'd been sitting for too long or what but they were very mushy. I like to have a dolma and be able to feel like I'm biting into the grape leaf. The grape leaf wrapping on these dolmas tasted soggy, which isn't a big win in my book.

Probably won't be back.
author: Megan D.

description: I've been told that this place isn't super traditional with their falafals, but I dont care. They make them with some spice that gives it an extra kick. Their shawarma and wraps are pretty top notch as well. The staff are usually pretty nice to me too.
author: Edmund L.

description: Delicious lamb shawarma, falafel, dolmas, kubeh, baklava...etc! Very nice owner, and prices not bad for expensive SF. 5/5 would recommend for quick lunch or dinner. A absolute favorite of mine!
author: Nichole P.

description:
The best falafels I've ever had.  I didn't know they could taste that good!

Small, hole in the wall cafe with excellent food.  Perfect lunch spot!
author: Nikki W.

description:
The falafel here is freaking delish, and that's all you need to know (of course that's not all I ate).

Was grocery shopping next door and stopped in to see what they had. I initially thought it was a Mediterranean grocery store, but was happy to see they had fresh food and goods.

Ordered the Super Falafel which has hummus, eggplant, potatoes, lettuce, tomatoes, tahini sauce, and served in lavash bread. I absolutely loved all the textures. The homemade hot sauce is delish, especially accompanied with the homemade tahini sauce. I probably should have taken a few to go (seriously).

I also ordered half a dozen dolmas and ate them all on the way back. So flavorful and tender. 

I was too full to try any of their Turkish delight or other desserty noms but next time for sure.

SO good.
author: Shereen A.

description: Taste was good. However description stated plates would come with pita bread well not it didn't. So it was a little disappointing to have to eat shawarma and hummus with another kind of bread.
author: Natalia E.

description:
BEWARE OF THIS DISGUSTING ESTABLISHMENT. It was the WORST experience I have ever had at a restaurant in my LIFE. For starters, the place was filthy. Dirt and trash littered on the floor, the bathroom was in a tiny corner in the back of the kitchen tucked away behind seemingly brand new cleaning supplies which had never been opened, and the toilet looked like it hadn't been cleaned in weeks.

It was unbearably hot in there, apparently air conditioning doesn't exist in that part of SF. The workers were somewhat friendly, and to be fair he did give us a free side of hummus after he screwed up my order. 

The food tasted okay, although it was extremely overpriced and we found a HAIR in our salsa. The three of us ordered chicken shawarma sandwiches and were constantly grabbing fresh napkins because of how messy, oily, and poorly prepared the food was as it kept falling apart. 

To top it all off, later that evening we all got food poisoning. Vomiting, diarrhea, headaches, and even now the following morning our stomachs are in knots. I will NEVER go back to this place even if they paid me. Do yourself a favor, and if a place looks unsanitary completely avoid it!
author: Jared M.

description: Avocado falafel was alright. This place is okay. The service is not the best. You order at the counter and when we were standing in line, the guy skipped over us... twice. Not cool. The food comes out pretty quickly though. The other guy who is cooking is pretty kind. This place is also a grocery store as well in case you wanted some Mediterranean groceries.
author: Julie L.

description: The owner was not very friendly. The place looked dirty, the food didn't seem fresh and they were very pricey. The guy used his finger to clean off the extra hummus. The cucumbers were bitter and tasted i
author: Jackie G.

description:
This place makes the best falafel. I often crave the flavors of this place and probably make a trip here at least once a month or once every few weeks.

I have tried the chicken kebab plate and will get side orders of falafel or babaghanoush or hummus. The dolmas is really good too.

I've also had the veggie plate and it hits the spot.  Flavors are heavenly.
author: Elaine H.

description: My favorite falafel in the city-  the falafel are fresh, crispy, and have just the right amount of spice.  The kubeh is tasty too!  Been going here for years- and will keep coming back!
author: John T.

description:
Excellent falafel and shawarmas. I've been coming for a while and it's a favorite spot from the lady's childhood.

The portions are fairly decent and the ingredients are all very fresh.

Service is usually good but I've had some brusk service a couple of times, especially when it gets crowded.
author: Art O.

description:
I never saw myself as a falafel guy, but this place made me believer! I always thought that I didn't like it, but in actuality, I've never tasted great ones UNTIL NOW!

I ordered a dozen falafels ($6) w/ a side of hummus ($5.00).

The falafels are delicious! Crispy on the outside and nice and light on the inside. I hate it when falafels feel so dense, but there's a perfect balance that exists when eating it here. For an added cherry on top of the experience, make sure to grab a side. My side of choice is hummus. I could literally dip and down the dozen, but self control...as I would love to enjoy it for the week.

Thank you Sunrise Deli! I hope to be back!
author: Vincent L.

description: I am very dissatisfied by their food quality and the prices. I ordered two plates from UberEats and they charged me $4 more + delivery fee. The food arrived cold and was very over priced
author: Pedram T.

description: I ate here recently and though I didn't get sick, I was really grossed out after a trip to their bathroom. I walked by 2 guys smoking cigarettes while prepping the food. Eew. The bathroom is tiny, dirty and the sink was occupied by a bucket so I couldn't really wash my hands without unloading it. Thought this place was the real deal because it's been around forever, but it's a little too real for me. Avoid until the health department checks these guys out.
author: Maria R.

description: Veg combo plate and falafel were so good but they forgot to give us pita bread for all 4 of our entrees :(
author: Jessica N.

description: Don't let appearances fool you, as It almost did me. Super nice people an FAB Food. Terrific tastes at reasonable prices. Highly recommend.
author: Audrey C.

description:
The food tasted OK, but I couldn't finish it, because I was disgusted when a cockroach crawled up the wall. The floors, chairs, and tabletops were sticky, which confirmed in my mind that they do not clean the place well.

It's too bad, because I really like Middle Eastern food and wanted a good place to get it in my neighborhood.
author: Mike L.

description: I love the hummus and falafel of this place.  Great sandwiches.  I had his shawarma one time and it was not bad really.  It is my comfort food since I am fro Jerusalem.
author: Abraham T.

description:
I came across this gem during my travels. The Falafel really is delicious! I had the Falafel wrap with the works (avocado & eggplant) total cost for lunch $10. 
They also offer traditional mediterranean desserts like Baklava which you can buy per piece.
author: Monique C.

description:
Food :

I've tried the wraps and the plates...  The meat in the wrap was straight from the fridge ice cold and not fully cooked,  the lavash which was used for the wrap was also cold.  The plate wasn't any better... After the two attempts at this place even though the reviews said they make good falafel I would never go back to try anything they have to offer. 

Restaurant : 

It's a health hazard! I've never seen any restaurant at this state I'm actually surprised they are still open and not shut down by department of health!
author: Yas J.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and have been mentally projecting good thoughts to the proprietors of this place every time I walk by in the hope that they will turn this place into the Mediterranean food destination it should be. I walk in every few months with the intention of ordering something, but I more often than not I back out before committing. When I do commit, I'm usually disappointed. They make great falafel balls. Sometimes. Actually, that one time two years ago when they made them fresh and I saw them pluck them directly from the fryer. But sometimes they seem to have old falafel balls hanging around that they reheat. They also heat up the chicken and lamb that was I assume was shaved off the (cold, unheated, despondent) shawarma log over by the front window sometime earlier this morning. 

The salads in that refrigerated deli thing look nice, but the menu is complicated and hard to understand. Can I order a small salad? How much is that? How might I get a combination plate that has a bit of all the best stuff? No? You just want to give me a blob of hummus and some meat dropped on top of it with a pita on the side? Okay, then. The menu (apparently painted many years ago by an apprentice sign painter) frustrates me. I've spent a lot of time trying to understand how to order here. 

Look. I hate to break it to you, but this family run establishment lacks passion. In a big way. What if you put some music on (your choice) and cleaned up the tables and swept and mopped the corners and painted the walls and had a bit of fun while you make food? I wouldn't mind. Maybe look just a tiny bit happy to see people who walked in. I'm so sorry to say it, but this restaurant feels like the family who runs it can barely stand to be there. I think about this place a lot (maybe too much) and look in every time I walk by. But I eat here only when I absolutely need a Mediterranean fix. This is my neighborhood, and I want to support every restaurant I can in this is foodie dead zone. I'd come here every week if they gave me a reason. But each time I try it I wonder at how they are still in business.
author: Casey C.

description:
Near my house and been on Irving for quite a few years now. I can't even remember what business was in this store before thats how old this place is.

If I wasn't on such a low carb and low oil free diet I'd frequent this place much more. I'm a huge fan of their falafels and meat of choice schwarmas. When I"m less diet conscience I'll come back here.
author: Jude N.

description:
Overall not bad, just not great either.  Ordered 4 plates to go-- lamb schwarma, chicken schwarma, lamb kebab and chicken kebab plates. Would not recommend the schwarma  plates-- swimming in hummus (which was good, but just too much), no lettuce/tomato as advertised. Kebab plates were better with an option of sides-- cucumbers/tomatoes had a nice crunch, and the pickled beets were tasty.

Maybe the wraps are better?
author: Amy D.

description:
Health hazard.. Bread had mold.. This place is dirty.. Quality of meat is low.. 

This place is for the birds.. Dont be a sucker..

Peace
author: Sheik S.

description:
Quick update with a bit more detail.

Great falafel, big (~2.5-2.75 inch diameter x 1.5-2 inches thick). Watch the guy make it by scooping up the finely ground mix and using a scoop to drop it into the deep fryer. One of my favorite places for falafel, especially when they're freshly made, heavily seasoned with cumin and black pepper. They're pretty sizable, so one falafel will take a couple of bites to get through. Which is great, because you can experience the crispy exterior and the cakelike interior in one bite!

Their shawarma isn't cut right off the skewer; it's kept in a heating tray. It's pretty juicy!

The kibbeh is one of my favorite things here. It's like a ground beef corn dog. They should sell THIS at ball games; I have it on good authority that it goes pretty well with beer. 

Greek salad was not available, unfortunately, so we could balance our proteins with some fiber.

Good for takeout, and there are a couple of tables if you feel like dining in. There are maybe three other places in the neighborhood where you can get this kind of quick Mediterranean style food, but this is my choice for kibbeh.
author: Jade V.

description:
The falafel was quite good even though the texture inside was a bit dry.  I would definitely buy it again though.  It's made to order, and fresh does make a big difference with falafel.  I also got a lamb and beef shawarma which was good, but I have mixed thoughts about it. The meat had good flavor and was moist. But even though I ordered extra meat, the portion did not seem that generous.  The sandwich was much smaller than I expected and there was not much else in the pita wrap.  I'd definitely go back, and want to give it four stars because it's the best falafel I've had in SF or the northern peninsula.  But $10 was really high for a very small sandwich.

The exterior and the interior of the store do seem grungy, but the table was clean and I don't judge mom and pop restaurants for their decor.  The food is good, and fresh.
author: Ilsa S.

description:
I ordered some lunch from Sunrise Deli for delivery. Free delivery with a $10 minimum. 

[THE FOOD]
Lamb Shawarma Sandwich ($8.00)
Greek Salad Plate ($8.00) - add chicken ($2.50)

At first, I was pretty stoked about how heavy the bag was. Nothing is more disappointing than a scrawny shawarma. So you can imagine my disappointment when I bit into it and found my lamb to be incredibly dry. Not only that, but in the middle of the wrap, I actually had completely burnt chunks of meat that were totally inedible. 

The Greek Salad plate was disappointing as well. The cucumber chunks were gigantic, like almost longer than they were round. The chicken was also dried and overcooked. 

Overall, I don't believe I will be ordering from this place again. The woman who delivered the meal was very pleasant at least.
author: Cara O.

description: If a deli looks dirty, how clean will the food preparation be?  The place is dirty.  The door mat looks like it hasn't been cleaned in weeks.  The plants outside are neglected.  The chrome frames on the chairs need to be scrubbed clean.  The place looks disorganized.  Yet customers are there to order food.  We ordered lunch to take out.  The food was good; but I was concerned that if the management can't keep the place clean, how clean is the food prep?!
author: Diana S.

description:
The falafels at this place is amazing ! They are so fresh and flavorful. I came here for takeout and got a falafel wrap and a chicken kabob plate. 

Falafel wrap ($7) - 5 stars. It was so full of falafel, veggies and hummus that made it really messy to eat. The falafels were really the star of this. They were perfectly crunchy and had so much flavor, really stood out from other falafels that I've had.

Chicken kabob plate ($12) - 3 stars. It had a decent amount of chicken but I thought it just lacked flavor. It came with 2 sides so my sister tried the rice/lentils and babagonoush. The rice and lentils were good. The other was just alright. Kind of lacked flavor there. 

Couple other notes, parking kind of sucks being on Irving. If you eat in, you order, eat, and then pay. Service is a bit slow. It took us about 15 mins to get our food and were the only ones there. 

Would definitely come back for falafels and maybe will try their shawarma next time.
author: Celia Z.

description: GET THE FALAFELS. SOO GOOD. A friend brought falafels from here to a bonfire one time and they were amazing. Ever since then I have ordered them with tahini and its incredible! Made when you order so they don't get really dry.  I have yet to try other items from here because Im obsessed with the falafels too much.
author: Thielson D.

description:
Their lamb plate was really dry and flavorless. The portion was also very small and their wasn't any vegetables or sides to complement the lamb. I had it served on a foil tray which I thought was kind of weird. The ingredients lacked freshness and tasted bland.

Only go to this place if you want falafels... But even then, their falafels weren't as hot or crisp as I'd like them.
author: Phillip K.

description:
WARNING: FOOD POISONING FROM THIS ESTABLISHMENT 

My two friends and I had lunch here Friday March 13th. As we waited for our food we asked to use their bathroom which is in the back room. The back room had a horrible stench and my friend couldn't even bare to use their restroom because it was that filthy. The sink was brown and disgusting as well. 

Next they brought out our food and got one of our orders wrong. My friend didn't even complain. She simply asked for a side of hummus with the wrong order they had already made. 

Then we grab the salsa container, and what do you know, there's a hair in it. What do we do? Take it out, not complain, and continue eating because of how hungry we were and because we understand mistakes happen. 

So Saturday night one of my friends starts getting nauseous. Then I call the other and he is also throwing up. Last is me I start vomiting. The only thing we all ate in common was the chicken shawarma served to us on Friday. We all have had headaches, hot sweats, vomiting, and body aches. 

I called them today to explain all of this and to get a refund. The manager denied it, was rude, and hung up on me. 

I will be calling the health department today. Please beware of this place.
author: Elizabeth Q.

description:
Two words: FOOD POISONING. A few of my friends and I came to this establishment based off of the ratings/yelp reviews posted. Boy, were we in for a rude awakening. 

I have absolutely no idea how this restaurant is recommended by trip advisor/ or has such great reviews from the past. The food itself did taste good, but the establishment was extremely dirty and all 3 of my friends and I  had food poisoning the day after. We should have left right away after seeing how extremely dirty the place was, AND finding a hair in the sauce. Instead, we decided to give them the benefit of the doubt. 

What bothers me the most is the fact that we called the restaurant after we all had food poisoning to let them know and they were extremely rude. It is as if they have no concern for their guests. Our health was affected by this and if they would have just cooperated and shown even the slightest bit concern, I may not even be writing this review right now. I'm honestly appauled. 

Please, do yourself a favor and DO NOT eat here. There are plenty other Mediterranean places in SF that will not leave you with the same outcome.
author: Katerina C.

description: love this place. it's my go to spot for affordable authentic med cuisine.  they're always really nice and their food is off the chain.
author: shar d.

description:
I'd hoped Sunrise might be a diamond in the rough with fantastic Mediterranean food lurking behind a cover of drab metal furnishings, smell of cooking oil, and  lackluster looking display cases.  Nope.  It was just what it appeared to be: good enough food served in ample portions amidst drab metal furnishings, the smell of cooking oil, and lackluster looking display cases.  Sometimes a book really can be judged by its cover.  

At Sunrise, you order at the counter based on a posted menu then take a seat to be served.  My falafel plate ($7.99) was a full platter divided in thirds with one third devoted to a very good tomato/cuke salad, one third devoted to precooked, barely warm, not very wonderful tasting falafel-topped lettuce, and one third filled with a slightly runny hummus that could've used some extra something.  With the exception of the tomato/cuke salad, the flavors were just okay, nothing to crave.  The platter was served with an ample side of pita.  

So, the food isn't in the same league as my new fave (Zaki Kabob House in Albany) but I can't argue about the portions.  What they put on that plate, should you choose to down it all, will have you waddling out with a 5 month food-baby.  Add some baklava (appears to be purchased elsewhere) and chocolate & nut-encrusted halvah and you'll leave about 8 cm dilated. 

Sodas and juices in a cooler at the rear but no Diet Coke (wah).
author: Tracey A.

description:
Avocado falafel all the way. Best falafel ever. Amen.

Since my first AF here, I have gone a total of 5 times in the last two weeks (twice at the Berkeley location)...and still counting! Oh, and for some reason, the Irving St location has tastier and more spicy falafels than the Berkeley one (probably more fresh?). But still, you just have to try. 

Ambience not so good, but ya kind of just forget once you dig into the deelish food.
author: Camille E.

description:
It's crunchy all around. 
Yet, it's not round.
It's kinda like a mini burger patty.
And, soft on the inside.
It's nice and spiced, even a little spicy.
It's deep fried and greasy. 
Greasy like soak and see-through the paper bag greasy. Fresh Prince would approve.
It comes warm- fresh and greasy.
O, yeah, did I mention it's greasy???
But, but, but, it's DELICIOUSLY GREAZZZYY!!!
It's legit!
What is it, you ask?

It's the BEST DAMN FALAFEL that there ever was, that's what!!

Sunrise makes some dadada bombbbb falafel. Trust me. If you didn't think you'd like falafel, just come here and you'll be a belieber. Don't just get one.. or two. Get at least 1/2 dozen, which will only set you back $3.49. But, keep in mind, that's only going to hold you over for the car ride home. So, probably better to get a dozen..or two. And that's if you want to be nice and share with others or you can just hog it for yourself.

While I would give the falafel 5 stars, I have to knock the shawarma, sadly. The thing was hard to eat with some gnarly grisly dry meat.

I repeat: Go for the falafel, not the shawarma. This is a no frills, in and out, handle your business, get your falalalafel fix and go place. Perfect for a quickie!
author: Angela W.

description: The falafel here is really good if you can get them fresh and piping hot. They've got a crunchy crust, and the inside is soft and moist. The herbs and spices make them really flavorful, and they use enough sesame seeds to give it that toasty nuttiness. The taste is a good mix of saltiness, zest, and spice. For less than $6 for a dozen, I think they're priced pretty well too.
author: Nei N.

description: This was my first time here and I'm not usually into falafel. I just started liking hummus but ther falafel was pretty good! Very flavorful and yummy crunchy! My friend brought me here and made me try it. I would DEFINTELY recommend eating it when u first get it. Hot is better than cold. Plus if you eat it fast you may not notice oil intake. You can buy just one, six or a full dozen, OR more if you like. Also had some of the chocolate halva, that was pretty yummy too. Either way super delish and would definitely go again. Don't forget to look out for their food truck. Only gave 4 stars cuz haven't tried that much stuff. Will update later on next visit.
author: Austin C.

description: Had the vege plate. It was amazing. The falafels were just made fresh and were delicious. The large was actually too large. Hummus was great as well as all of the vege. Also picked up a sesame desert thing (forgot name) and was also delicious.
author: Will D.

description:
Who the hell knew you could find the best falafels in the city on Irving St????????? Heck, I had the best falafels of my life here. I was watching the dude frying up the falafels right in front of me, that's how fresh they were -- and trust me, you can taste the difference.

I ordered the veggie plate, which came with super generous portions of hummus (tarty, creamy and delicious) and fresh cucumbers and tomatoes. I really could not believe how good everything tasted.

Don't understand the complaints about service -- everyone was so nice here. Prices are more than reasonable for the quality of food. Tables were a bit sticky, but whatevs. I'm thinking I'll be back at least once a week!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I finally tried this place after being told by friends it was good. San Francisco is infected with many (many) bland, overpriced "mediterranean" restaurants that serve mediocre food, usually messy, and overpriced.

This was not the case at Sunrise .I ordered the chicken shawarma and it was really good! the guy at the counter was polite, etc. However, this place could use a little help in the appearance of the place - they have boxes piled in the windows, the inside looks like it hasn't been updated in ages, and the drinks are wayyyy in the back. You can't even see the guy cooking the food from the street because one window is blocked by the neighboring green grocer.

If they would just take a little time and put in a little effort into their appearance, it would mean more sales. They don't have to go all hipstery doofus, or start serving shiitake mushrooms just make the front of the place more inviting, and be consistent with the food and it will do even better.
author: Greg D.

description: This place has improved in the past year since the haight location has closed.   the falafel used to be dry, but its better.   Happy to see the improvment and ill be back.
author: Johnny C.

description:
The food is good!

However they tend to close whenever they feel like it. Many times have I tried to go here for some food and they have been closed well before their posted times. They even leave their sign on.
author: Albert F.

description:
My husband and I have been here several times, but this evening has us wondering if we'll ever return. 
First off let me say that the service is friendly and professional. The service is not in question, but the quality and quantity of the food is. 
On the previous occasions we've visited, I was very satisfied with the serving size of the large schwarma  plate. I would normally be able to eat my fill and still have enough left over for lunch the next day. Also the portions of meat were heartier and there was a good balance between all items on the plate. It was truly worth $12.00. 
Tonight, though, I was very disappointed. The food was ok, but the plate was small and the ratio of hummus to the schwarma was very lopsided. It was as if my schwarma was a little island in a lake of hummus. Then they gave us each one pita, which we eventually had to ask for more. 
When we first received the plates of food we honestly thought that they didn't hear we wanted the large plate and gave us the small plate as a mistake. When my husband went to pay, he saw that they charged us for the large. We didn't argue, the men were so sweet. 
So as I write this, I do so with bittersweet feelings. I recommend that if you do go, stick to the kabobs or the pita wraps.
author: Jamye K.

description: I literally walked into this place blindly and thought "man some falafels sound good" and was floored to see the incredibly affordable prices of $4 for 1/2 dozen & $6 for 1 dozen fresh falafel. As soon as I placed my order for 1/2 dozen, they came straight out of the fryer and into my to go bag. These things are no joke! For less than $4.50, I can't think of many better deals in San Francisco. 100% will be back to try some of the other options but definitely recommend the falafels to start with! The guy running the shop also looks like the OG godfather of the neighborhood, much respek
author: Daniel C.

description: I was impressed with this place! The Falafels are extraordinary, best I've ever tried. Gyros are pretty good too. Friendly neighborhood shop with a mom 'n pop vibe.
author: Briget P.

description: 3.5 stars. I've come here a few times to get the falafel. I just happened to have stumbled upon this spot as i had an appt nearby one day and decided to drop in. The falafels are made to order. Since they are fried it won't be stay crispy sitting around, so they fry it when you order it. So, if you are coming from far away, you may want to call it in. I ordered when i walked in and it took almost 12-15 minutes and on a weekend, it's not convenient to park. I haven't tried the dishes, but have bought to-go most of the time.
author: Tiffany W.

description: The reviews weren't lying. Their falafels and hummus are amazing! One of the best bargain meal options here in the City.
author: Cornel E.

description: This is a nice, local deli with Middle Eastern style food. I had the chicken shawarma and their falafel. Both were pretty good but I wasn't blown away by either. The atmosphere inside is very plain and minimal - not the kind of place most would go to hang out for any length of time. I'd recommend ordering ahead and picking up your food to go. I'll do that the next time.
author: R S.

description:
My dad brought home falafel for the family. This place, with the original store owners, used to have the best falafel in the city. The falafel today was embarrassing for our Arab cuisine. 

The falafel was soggy, tasted like bread and, bland tasting. The saddest part was the inside. Typically a lush and fresh green. These falafel were yellow and disgusting. We are so dissapointed. Not to mention how overpriced the falafel are. Won't be coming back ever again.
author: Tony A.

description: Sunrise Deli is as good as it gets. THe falafel completely excedes it's reputation, they are crispy, fresh and always made to order. The service is friendly, and all of the food is incredible. The hidden gem to me about this place though are the dolmas. They are the best I've ever had. This is an SF institution and you truly haven't lived if you haven't been here.
author: Emma H.

description:
I can't be absolutely sure, but I think this is the place we stopped at  to buy a few middle-eastern things (mostly my sister).  We had already eaten lunch or I would have been tempted to eat here. The food looked legit. 

We couldn't resist the homemade turkish delight. It was expensive but man or man, probably the best Turkish delight I've ever had. Of course, I've never had it fresh. It has always come out of a box.  They were super nice and gave us a sample of their fresh falafel for free. Delicious!
author: Nora S.

description:
The Super Falafel is what I had to get, since there is eggplant as well as other goodies.   I have had falafel wraps before and even though this place is highly reviewed, I found the "Super" Falafel to be good, but nothing spectacular and fairly small as well.  I really could not taste the eggplant, falafel or other ingredients, except the tahini, which came through in some bites; but not all. I wish there had been more flavor, or at least as much as other places, like this little (and I mean little!) place on Judah, which had falafel in every bite.  I wish this one had more falafel.  Perhaps I should have just ordered falafel with the sauce.  The Kubeh are fantastic, full of flavor, a new treat.  Oh, and the spicy oil is VERY spicy! :) 

Everyone was super nice and patient, and if in the neighborhood again I would swing by for falafels and kubeh, and perhaps that soft looking bread ring.
author: Delicious B.

description:
My lamb shawama had so much sauce that 90% of it ended on my jeans within seconds of having a bite. Finally we gave up and just ate the insides with a fork and bypassed the thick pita around it.

The shawarma had tons of meat that was cut very small. It was mostly meat and picked onions, I didn't see any other ingredients in there. The sauce was incredibly thin so you didn't get the taste of the creamy greek yogurt and spices that is usually in the tzatziki sauce that I love so much.

I also got a side (6) of dolmades which was a pretty good deal at $4. The dolmades had a tasty flavor but nothing out of the ordinary, I've had exponentially better before.

All in all a tasty experience but not the best food truck there. Oh well. To experimenting!
author: Emily G.

description:
The best falafel I've had in the bay area. Unlike the rest of the locations in SF, this one actually looks like a deli inside and has some Mediterranean foods for sale in the corner of the store.

But where the hell do you get those pink pickled israeli radishes?!
author: Jon T.

description: Disgusting . I asked for a regular falafel sandwich . The guy was wiping his hand in literally everything around , his pants , the counter , the area under the sink then he grabbed the falafel and square them with his hand in the sandwich and then was grabbing the remade salad with his hand and putting it in the sandwich . The least I can write the I almost gonna call the manager but thought yelp is better
author: Ahmed S.

description:
Great falafel!

But the cashier at the food truck today was the worst!  The whole time a saw a cigaret tucked behind his ear ( I have never visited a food truck this lax about this ) and could sense right away the type of interaction this would be. 

When taking my order he yelled unnecessarily loud and wouldn't look me in the eye. He yelled next as loud as he could right at me. I was the third in line with two patrons after me. They were both served before I was while the staff exchanged jokes and kept looking at me. The cashier pointed to my receipt and made sure it was the last receipt to be made by the cook. The cook shook his head but prepared my falafel last anyway. While this occurred the cashier stared at me with an intimidating look. 
I was polite as always and his attitude toward me was vile from the start. I did nothing other than make my order and was met with this level of disrespect. Not to mention that the cashier flirted with one of the patrons in line after me when delivering her falafel. 

I have visited the deli location and have never experienced treatment like this.
author: RobertO Q.

description: Went to eat shawarma after seeing good reviews on yelp.Extremely disappointing food.I repent eating the food.It was tasteless and not fresh.Very bad experience.Felt like throwing up.Meat was chewy.Not recommending to anyone .
author: Mary U.

description:
I think Truly Mediterranean has found a competition.  We came here after Sunday church service.  This place was convenient for us because it's on our way home.  As for Truly Mediterranean, it'll be out of our way.  

Hubby got lamb shawarma... I say truly mediterranean is better, but still good.  

i got the  falafel plate... their falafel wins over truly, beware there's a kick to it.  But MmMmmmm so delicious.  

hummus... hmm i can't judge yet.  Sunrise hummus is more creamy and runny, good for dipping.  Truly has lemony flavor.  Again it's a preference.  If you want a dip, go to Sunrise.  If you like hummus with your wrap, it's Truly.  

Place is kinda rundown and service is alright.  Will definitely be a good lunch place.
author: Claire J.

description:
Sometimes I wake up in the morning and realize I've been dreaming about the avocado falafel pita sandwich from Sunrise Deli. It is one of the most delicious meals you can get in SF. The falafel is perfectly fried with a crispy outside and fluffy inside. The hummus is creamy and the pickled cabbage really completes this mediterranean masterpiece!

The staff at this place is very friendly and casual, the food is phenomenal and the prices are totally reasonable. One of my favorite lunch spots in the whole city!
author: Jasmine M.

description: I liked my falafel wrap and cucumber -yogurt salad but unfortunately have to give this place only 2 starts . Because place as dirty as hell ! It looks like warehouse. Floor is dirty , tables and chairs are all sticky !    Common. Are people who owns it that much lazy  ?! Not even clean once a day ... 0 zero respect to the customers
author: N L.

description: These guys are all "Look at us, we're the best falafel in the city!" and I'm all like "Dude, whateves, prove that ####." and they're like "BAM! Falafel ####### domination!" and I'm like "Whoa. Uh, can I have a fig cookie too?" and they're like "You may."
author: Daniel E.

description:
Avoid the meat, go for the falafel. 

Chicken and lamb were both dry and flavorless. 

Falafel is ok when it's fresh. There's better elsewhere in the city.
author: J. M.

description:
Hands down the best falafel in san fran. Great salads and well worth a visit.

However staff are massively incompetent and inconsistent. Make sure you stand over them when they prepare your food. There is always a new person with no idea whats going on or what kind of portion to serve.

I started going to this place in 1994. I love the food.  I loathe the service.

5 star food 2 star service = 3 stars overall
author: AL S.

description: Very disappointed; ordered three meals between us, two gyros and a chicken plate, all three were stone cold. The food was very average in taste.
author: Fred K.

description: Food was cold and the hummus was just o.k. I had the Chicken Kabob plate for $12.
author: Rod M.

description:
The worst food and service I have had in SF so far. I went in and asked for Hummus and 1/2 dozen falafels. It was obvious when I ordered that I spoke Hebrew by the way I pronounced the menu ... well get back to this .My friend had the shwarma plate which I advised against. I told him not to order the shwarma because the meat was just sitting on the rack out to the elements without the heater being on, and spinning which is just simply having meat sitting out all day...GROSS. They cooked it for a while on the grill and then threw it on some hummus for the plate, which was small and over priced for the size of the dish. 

The hummus tasted like it was out of a jar of paint and quite possibly was the worst I have ever had. I would have rather gone and picked up some store brand hummus out of the cvs across the street. Would have been exponentially better.

 I asked and was told the hummus was going to be hot and then when it came out it was cold. I asked if there was a mistake and the owner said that no one ever heats up hummus and that he was not going to do it for me, even though he literally just said he would when I ordered. He asked me where I ever saw someone heat up hummus and was waiting for me to say Israel. I didn't, payed and left.  

The falafel was not bad Ill give them that, but I wouldn't piss on this place if it was on fire.  

Try Old Jerusalem in the mission, went there the other day. The food was great  and the owner couldn't have been nicer.
author: Max S.

description:
Popped in on my lunch to finally check out their shawarma wraps. I opted for the lamb/beef, and unlike other places I've tried, their lamb/beef was tough and chewy. Beef can be a struggle to eat at times, but lamb? I'm beginning to think I only had beef in my wrap.  I've never had hummus in a wrap with meat before either so the texture of those two components didn't get along well at all.  Don't think I'll EVER be ordering it again. Probably should have went with the chicken instead. :-/ Thank God for tooth floss! 

The man working the counter was also frying up some fresh felafels so I bought one for .75 cents.  It was super good. Crispy, flavorful and not dense at all.  I'll probably be back for more of these little balls of delight at some point.  

Overall, service was good; food seems to be hit or miss.  Try the felafel, ditch the lamb/beef shawarma.
author: Shamina K.

description:
This is purely for the food truck parked at the Streatfood Park in Soma. 

By far. The. Best. Falafal. EVER. Or least that I have tasted outside of the middle east. Moist. Flavorful. Warm. Toasty. DELISHUSSSS...

Wasnt the biggest fan of the long ass line we had to wait in. But that is a testament to how awesomeness the falafal is :)
author: Michelle I.

description:
I side with the majority here, the falafel is very very good. It was a falafel revelation for me. Crusty crust, dense chewy inside that was not cloying or raw or any of those things, just a perfect falafel. Plus they sell them by the dozen. For $60 you could have lunch for two somewhere, or you could buy ten dozen falafel here and feed an army. I bought two dozen for $12, which I have been eating for several days, and I can say that the car smelled very nice going home and it has smelled very nice ever since.

Hummus was too thin, nothing special for me, just a falafel filling. The cucumber-yogurt salad was very nice, and I really liked their hot sauce and bowl of tiny chopped fresh parsley. For their sandwiches they use an excellent very fresh lavash bread made by a local bakery in Gilroy, or you can buy a huge bag of it for three dollars.

Calling it a "deli" is an overstatement. There are a few shelves with a few items. As a restaurant it is equally sparse, a nice menu of wraps, salads, plates, but not very extensive. It's the combination.

Staff was very friendly. Prices quite reasonable. Like I said, you could feed a small army here for $60 if you buy the bulk items, a little mercenary force if you order the prepared wraps and plates.
author: Gil S.

description:
2 Stars for the good food. LIke pretty darn good.

But -3 stars for the a-hole worker who rolled his eyes and sighed anytime we would ask a question or basically interact with him. We get it dude. You had a bad day. But that doesn't mean you have to treat us like we're annoying. Sorry we're indecisive sometimes or that not everyone knows what shawarma is. Sorry we misunderstood your mumbling reply and we couldn't hear you.

I've worked in customer service before too so I get it. There are some days you just don't want to be bothered.

But its your job to SUCK IT UP AND PUT ON A SMILE.

Safe to say we're never coming back.
author: Gregg H.

description:
I've been getting falafel here since I was a kid. After eating falafel in various locations around the world, I still think this is the best.

Honestly, the best thing here is the falafel. You can get a half dozen for a snack, or a full dozen to bring home a share. They fry them fresh and it's perfectly fried on the outside but not too oily on the inside. 

With so many other options on Irving, I'll grab some falafel here (maybe a walnut baklava sometimes) and get a drink elsewhere.
author: Crystal F.

description:
Nice owner.  Makes the customer service all better.  It was my first time ever to try a Falafel.  He gave me a  free one to try that was hanging out cold but it was still good.  We had the food and it was yummy.  Personally I like the falafel with the dinner with the chicken kabab platter & chicken Kabab falafel sandwich but my hub likes the falafel by itself.  :P  I like it all wrapped up with stuff.  Very tastey!!  Loved it!  

I was so curious about the pistachio baklava so we bought 1 to try (IT was extremely YUM YUM NOM) & he didn't even charge in the end.  What a nice guy !  totally deserves a 5 star.  I'd go back for the yummy food any day!  

Personally this was inexpensive so worth getting and it's a pretty big portion tho it doesn't seem like it.  One sandwich will probably last me 2 meals!
author: Juila L.

description: Delicious food, good portion sizes, fast  and great customer service and affordable. We were very satisfied with our order. This place has the best falafel ever! We got six for $4, which is amazing. They were full of flavor, crunchy on the outside and just right on the inside. The shawarma platter was delicious; came on top of hummus. The pita was okay; could be better. I prefer fluffy, warm pita. This was dry, cold and flat.
author: Rabia Q.

description:
First time trying falafel so I didn't have much to compare it to, but to my taste buds it was phenomenal. I'd definitely would come back for the falafel.I decided on a meat that I don't ever have at home, so I tried to the lamb shawarma. It was a bit dry and tough, but overall it was very tasty. 

I'm a fan..for the falafels!
author: Jenna H.

description:
My first falafel-- the avocado falafel, to be specific. The falafel itself did not disappoint and the avocados were a great touch. However, there was a limited portion of avocado (and that knocked off a star, because I love me some avocado) and too much pickled cabbage, which almost took away from the amazing blend of falafel, hummus, and avocado. The pita pocket was toasty and just the way I liked it. Huge servings, so you'll be surely full, and if you were me, unable to finish the 99 cent Quickly's drink you got from across the street. However, the small Veggie Combo my friend got was way too expensive for the small ass serving she received. 

Overall, it was a good falafel experience, but I was a bit perturbed by the prices, which were a bit higher than what I assumed they were from my reading of Yelp reviews. I'll be back for that Turkish Delight though.
author: Rochelle C.

description:
TheFalafels are decent here.   I dread going in there when the owner is around.  He's a grumpy, unfriendly guy.  The son runs the food truck.  I try to go in for some fresh falafel when someone else is working the counter.  But, the owner is likey a control freak and comes out from the back when the help has bagged your falafels and he takes the payment.  He never says hello or thank you, just glares at you without a smile. I'd go in more often except I don't think customers need to be made to feel as if you're lining up to visit the soup Nazi like on the Seinfeld TV shows.  
So, I go in only 2x a year when I have a craving for some falafels.
author: Ry T.

description:
BEST falafel ever and you can see the guy kneading it (do they knead falafel?) right in front of you.

I ordered the falafel plate and was not disappointed. They pile up that hummus, let me tell ya. Everything is just cooked real well.

Minus one star because it's not the cleanest place and I think the chef or someone in the back kept swearing and screaming and it made me scared.
author: Carleen W.

description:
On the eve of the Lunar New Year 4707 all of my regular lunch stops in the Outer Sunset were packed.  I was picking out a few honey tangerines next door at the 22nd and Irving Produce Market when I glanced over and noticed the two vertical spits (one with lamb, one with chicken) in full view inside the right window of the Sunrise Deli & Café.  

When it comes to eating Middle Eastern food I'm a complete novice.  I can honestly think back and recall only two other occasions when I've had a falafel or a wrap.  After I made my purchase next door I stopped at the window to take a look.  The hot juices flowing down from the two meats invited me inside.  I browsed at the paper menu stuck on the opposite window.  The Chicken Shawarma sounded good or in my case it had ingredients that I am familiar with.

The prices they have posted inside (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/e02eHaL0toY64Tzodnx8_Q?select=5yFHIx67oiXMqXVgdo2QsQ) has gone up slightly from the prices on the paper menu.  In these tough times it's to be expected.  I ordered the sandwich and walked to the back of the restaurant to take a soda out of the refrigerated display.  They have a very good assortment of beverages to choose from.  The nice man asked me to take a seat and pay after I eat.

He brought me my Chicken Shawarma (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/e02eHaL0toY64Tzodnx8_Q?select=FHfY4kH96eBGRlWnjkseZA) just minutes later.  I gotta admit; I didn't expect it to be stuffed so full.  I picked up the pita sandwich and took a big bite.  I got a mouthful of juicy diced tomatoes, chicken breast and the delicious tahini sauce.  There was lots of chicken in there too.  According to the menu the chicken breast is marinated in lemon and garlic.  I tasted the lemon but not even the faintest bit of garlic.  There are thin strings of onion and chopped lettuce in the sandwich too, but I think the tasty sauce and the moist chicken made the difference.  I enjoyed the sandwich enough to pick up all of my crumbs and eat them too.

A lot of the items they have on display I'm not at all familiar with and I would have asked had they not been so busy.  Next time I'm nearby and feeling hungry I won't hesitate to make a return visit.  Very nice people too.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Fresh falafels and grilled meat pita sandwiches here are the bomb. (no terriorist pun intended) Desserts available also.
author: Tina L.

description: I ate from their truck and it was awful. I had the chicken shawarma and it was edible because I was starving but still couldn't finish it and would never eat it again. We also got the chicken kabob plate - hummus gross, rice and lentil undercooked, and the chicken just not tasty. I will never eat there again. Ended up throwing away an uneaten plate.
author: Ericka S.

description: We randomly dropped by for lunch, but had no idea what to get but we were pretty hungry.  I ended up getting a Chicken Shawarma Sandwich and it was delicious.  Decent sized portion, although I wouldn't have called it a sandwich, looked more like a taco/burrito with a pita wrap.  Lots of chicken meat, loved the tahini sauce.  So good, I left fully satisfied.
author: Karen L.

description: Were on a trip down highway one and my boyfriend says "find me a falafel" ..I trust yelp and stop at sunrise. We ordered 2 regular falafels and had a very nice, chill, friendly guy serve us. The food was great, the service was great, the atmosphere is a little grungy but it was way worth it for what we got! Yummmmmm
author: Nikki B.

description:
