Two stars for great service, awesome vegetarian fare, but the shawarma meat was horrible! The guy was great about swapping chicken instead, and it was just as bad. 

I showed it to some middle eastern friends to see if it was like a traditional thing or something, nope, just cheap quality. And from legendary Sunrise deli?! I am frankly surprised.

If you swap the meat supplier for the store, I will gladly make it "5-star", if only out of respect for the historic quality level from this place.
author: Mike S.

description: Excellent falafel one of the best in the city. Simple no frills counter service but the owner is very nice and accommodating. Never had anything there that wasn't good and very freshly made. Fully recommend!
author: David M.

description: Came in to try the place I have always walked by but never went into. Finally stepped through their doors after getting a KGB coupon deal. Ordered a $6.49 Avocado Falafel http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=CAveDmi9tYg3Gbs9VVnm2Q&select=4HHfY-xEFikkT3OJZjiFhw and $6.99 Lamb Shawarma http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=CAveDmi9tYg3Gbs9VVnm2Q&select=37-sDW6O_i_gKf3X7b1s7w. I think I prefer the Avocado Falafel. Both were a bit messy to eat. Most falafels I have eaten are not very good, but these were hot and crispy. I guess they really do sell the best falafels around. Next time I'll get a dozen falafels, it's only 5 or 6 bux.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Walking through the doors of Sunrise Deli brings floods of memories and nostalgia of my childhood days. My mom introduced me to this place when I was an adolescence. Their falafel is simply the BEST there is. I have never had falafel as great as Sunrise Deli's. The texture (CRUNCH!!! and tender insides) is sooo satisfying. The flavors merge very well and the spices dance around on your taste buds.
Also, the vegetarian dish is bomb! Babaganoush, hummus, rice & lentils, dolmas, cucumber & tomato salad, and a couple pieces of falafel balls really make it a hearty meal! The side options/dishes are fantastic too! I love this place!
author: Shannen L.

description: Stopped in this evening for dinner, got the large shawarma plate.  Pretty big portion for $12, came with meat and grilled onions in a humus ring with tomatoes and white sauce on top w a side of 4 pcs of humus.  Really good, and the cook working the shop was extremely friendly.  We had a very nice conversation while he worked.  Definitely will be back again.  Want to try some of the sandwiches / wraps in the future.
author: T. E.

description: Found this place while taking a lunch break from Golden Gate Park. We almost missed seeing it because it's one of those hole-in-the-wall places, but were fortunately walking rather than driving so spotted it next to a market. The shawarma & kofta plates were very tasty & reasonably priced. I would have given the food (not ambience, as it's very basic) 5 stars except the hummus was a little on the soupy side. We tried the chocolate halva as well, which was delicious & a great way to end a meal. Will definitely go back the next time we're in SF.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
The falafel is great here, and the dessert: superb! Get the falafel and make it a point to purchase dessert: the pistachio baklava. 

Other than the side orders, the combos can be a little pricey.
author: Lillian N.

description: Best falafel. Period. Basic interior with no frills but the meal amazed us. We went with family (including 3 yr old) and all enjoyed. Avocado Falafel sandwich in lavash with extra spice was a standout.
author: Jeremiah S.

description:
"The best falafel in town", they have posted outside.

I love middle eastern food, and this place is great for a quick snack. I dont know about the BEST when it comes to falafels, but when I'm craving them, this is the place to go. 
The area is convenient on Irving St. surrounded by bubble tea places.
Their falafels are never soggy and theyre always made fresh. They're perfectly crispy, but a little on the saltier side. I never get anything here except falafels, so I can't speak for anything else.
The staff is amazing and you get served quickly. The place is small, but most don't stay to eat anyways.
Definitely recommend trying this place when youre in the area!
author: Veronica L.

description:
I would assume most of these reviews are for the truck or majority of these reviewers have a low standard for what is considered clean. The place is basically a filthy stock room that wreaks of mold. 

Open employee drink containers by the food prep stations. Food handling is poor and unsanitary. Sure, cashier...handle money and prep food without washing hands.

Toilet and I are going to spend a lot of quality time together...gonna be hot (and still likely cleaner than this place).
author: Kris K.

description: Bought chicken kabob on a plate for dinner. Chicken was not completely cooked and ate about a quarter of it before I noticed. Needless to say, I did not enjoy the rest of my Friday night......would give negative star if I could
author: Doris N.

description:
The falafels are soooo good. They HAVE to be hot though! If they're only room temperature, they don't taste as good. 

HINT: popping them in the microwave for about 30 seconds helps :)
author: Erica A.

description:
We had gone to SF to run an errand. At 4, we still didn't have our lunch and found this cafe through yelp. So headed there since I haven't had shawarma for a very very long time. We were 3 adults and ordered a lot of food.

 2 of us had chicken shawarmas and I had lamb shawarma. Was great, but not out of the world great. We also tried the kubeh for the 1st time ever, kubeh is a wheat based dumpling with ground beef stuffing. We also had dolmas and pistachio baklavas, which were yum. Got a dozen of falafels to go as well. My spouse claims they are yummy as well.
author: Mia C.

description:
During my recent trip to Vancouver, I had what might have been the best falafel sandwich I've ever had.  So naturally, when I got back, I made a point of trying to find a good falafel joint here.  And one day, while walking down Irving, I caught sight of the sign outside Sunrise Deli that read, "the best falafel in town".  The best, eh?  With that, I had to go in and check them out.  

I ordered the Avocado Falafel sandwich and got a pretty decent amount of food - falafel, avocado, lettuce, tomato, hummus, and tahini sauce served in pita bread.  The falafel was already pre-cooked when I had ordered, so I'm not sure how long it was sitting there before I got inside.  The sandwich was pretty warm to the touch in the end, so I'm thinking that it may not have been that long.  Either way, the falafel was good, but not mind blowing.  Though, it did have a nice crispy/crunchy texture.

The sandwich as a whole was kind of the same....not bad, but not amazing.  The avocado portion was essentially a chunk dropped on the top of each half, which was disappointing since it was gone after about two bites.  Too bad they couldn't have diced it or something to spread it out a bit.  Also, I didn't care much for the tahini sauce, though it might just be my taste buds.  Regardless, I thought that the sauce was a little overwhelming and overshadowed the rest of the flavors.

Overall, the place is not bad, but the food but didn't win me over.  I must have missed the boat somewhere though because they have a lot of fours and fives on here.  Their sign proclaims to have the "best falafel in town", but I haven't tried enough of the other places in the city to say otherwise.  However, right or wrong, I know I've had better outside of the city/country.
author: Mike L.

description:
It has been a while since I have been here. I stopped by on Monday and had the lamb Shawarma. Yes, prices have gone up just a bit. Yet it is worth every bite because the food is always fresh and service is friendly and outstanding. 

One thing I recommend to friends when going to Sunrise Deli is to get a lamb or chicken Shawarma before 1 PM. The reason why is because later on in the day, the meat gets thinner. The lunch crowd always gets the best and choice pieces. So its kind of first in line sort of routine. 

Also, Sunrise has some of the best falafal, hummus, etc. This little place has always maintained freshness and quality. Well worth a visit if ever you are in the Sunset District. Sunrise is now open till 9 PM. Credit cards are accepted but owner asks that it be for nothing under $10.00
author: Jonathan F.

description:
LOVE Mediterranean food! Falafel, hummus, tabouli, dolma, I'll eat it ALL! So when my friends and I spotted this little cafe along Irving Street, I suggested we try it!

After looking over the menu, I became even MORE excited when I saw they had a falafel AVOCADO sandwich!! I knew right then and there I had to get that! :) My friends decided to share the falafel plate (falafel on a "bed" of lettuce & tomato, hummus, tahini, and pita bread).

So, here's the verdict: the falafel was delicious. Not enough avocado. Generous portion size. The hummus was kind of thin and watery...not good for dipping pita bread in :P

The service was kind of eh, but it didn't affect my overall experience. 

I'd probably be back to try some other things! Maybe I'll forgo the veggie options and order some MEAT!
author: Kei H.

description:
OMG, how in the world have I not reviewed Sunrise yet?

This is easily the best falafel I've ever had. It made me a falafel person, which I wasn't before. I don't know what type of narcotics they use in their seasonings, but it's just unbelievably good. It's fresh, spicy (but not too spicy), and flaky and just UGH, it's perfect. It doesn't taste fried, either! 

The only thing I've ever gotten here (and will probably continue to get forever) is the avocado falafel sandwich. First of all, it's a LOT of food. This doesn't mean you won't finish it, even if you think you can't take another bite. 

Ingredients: Avocado, lots of falafel, pickled turnips (Lebanese sauerkraut?), lettuce, diced tomatoes, and hummus, all stuffed into a pita pocket.

This is a messy meal. Make sure you have napkins and/or a bib if you're anything like me. The hummus will be spilling out of the pita and tomatoes will be flying everywhere, but your tongue will be singing from how amazing this sandwich is. The hummus has this delicious lemony tang to it, which complements the turnips and falafel perfectly.

The guys at the counter can be gruff, but I suppose that's part of their charm. Once you've ordered, they invite you to take a seat, without pressuring you to pay until you're motioning to leave. There's a really home-y, I'm-in-my-long-lost-Middle-Eastern-grandma's-kitchen vibe here, and I like it a lot. I've also visited their location off Kearny Street, which is also great if you're grabbing food to go. 

Side note: If you like halvah, you NEED to try theirs. It's crumbly and completely delicious. They usually have a huge block of it in stock, and it's super cheap. And if you haven't tried halvah, I feel sorry for you, but also encourage you to try it here.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Got the vegetarian combo plate to go:  Mujaddara,Tabouli, Babaghanuj, Hummus, Tahini, Tomato and Cucumber Salad, with Falafel and Dolma, served with pita bread Hummus. I asked for olives and their pickled turnip slices (bright pink!)

As everyone else has said, the falafel are outstanding.  I love the food here.  This place is nice and clean, good service, heavenly pistachio baklava.  Most baklava is on the way to stale, this is fresh and loaded with  pistachios.

My only complaint is that everything was put into one container so it all slid together on the way home.  The only way around this is to order each thing separately into pint containers.  My advice: bring your own. Inconvenient, I know.
author: Pat P.

description:
Today Sunday 8/24/2014 5:30pm was it for me,  I'm done going here!  And here is why...  

Went in and  2 people were sitting at a table eating  and a couple were standing to order.  It wasn't hectic for the  ONE and only  employee that was taking her sweet time to assist the couple in front of me or even acknowledge us with a greeting  or I'll be with you in just a minute, NO!  none of  this type of customer service exists here. So don't expect it if you decide to go Here. 

Here is what made it  worst for me, and the reasons  I've decided not to ever come back to this place again.  I stood behind the couple to order AND finally almost 15 minutes later  the ONE employee who was making the falafels and running back and forth takes their order and then the couple got a table.  Another customer walks in and I'm the only one standing, she immediately acknowledges him and takes his order,  HELLLOOOO IM HERE!!  I should've said  BUT  waited  patiently and said to myself it's okay MAYBE JUST MAYBE SHE WILL ACKNOWLEDGE ME after she takes his order, well that didn't happen!   9 minutes later his food is ready and  as I'm about to say something to her another customer walks in and again she does the same thing again,  she wants  to take his order. At this point my blood is boiling,  she didn't even look at me it's like I'm invisible to her,  Meanwhile  the employee in the back walked towards the  prep area while picking his nose, and in a quick motion whipped his index with the apron it's like no one saw him!  COME-ON NOW!!  AT LEAST GO INTO THE BATHROOM AND DO THAT DONT DO IT WHILE WALKING TOWARDS YOUR "CUSTOMERS"!!!!!!!  Anyhow  I said to The female employee  "I've been here for 25 minutes standing you've took other people's orders whom walked in here after me and yet you wanna assist this customer whom just walked in ?!".  No apologies from her nothing,   all she said was "oh I thought you've been helped!!!".  WHAAT BY WHOM ?  THE FREAKING WALL??!  YOU ARE THE ONE WHO'S TAKING ALL CUSTOMERS' ORDERS!  AND IGNORING ME!   I ended up not ordering Thank god I walked out of there! .. With this service I'd rather starve! ..good luck Sunrise Deli you need it.
author: Adam T.

description: Two Chicagoans bought: 12 falafel basket (w/ 2 tahini sauces and a lentil soup), cucumber yogurt salad, two sodas and a few pitas.  We probably spent around $20 and had an absolute feast. The staff was nice, but the shop loses a point because it seemed pretty dirty and was weirdly cramped. Food to go in the park would be AMAZING in nice weather.
author: Jackie O.

description:
NB: this is *not* a Greek restaurant, it is Middle Eastern

* when the falafels are fried fresh they are INSANELY good (if they're not fried fresh then they're like any other falafel)
* their fries and eggplant is fried on the heavier side & doesn't add much when you throw it in the falafel for an extra $
* THEIR AVOCADO FALAFEL ROCKS! - i do wish they'd add more than just a few slices though
* other good standards: baklava/ hummus/ babaganoush/ yogurt dip

my fave falafel place in SF though is still: Ali Baba's in the Mission.
author: Anjali V.

description:
With a truck that says "Best Falafel in town, " I thought I should give it a try. 

I ended up ordering the avocado falafel (~$7): It was ok, but not good to give 4 stars. It just wasn't easy to eat and it got all over the place. I think they added way too much veggies with its dressing because it was way too sour and soaking into my hands. The falafel itself was very oily and over cooked because it was really dry inside.
author: Erica T.

description:
freshly deep fried falafel is tasty here. but the lamb schwarma roasted on a spit was more than a little disappointing. lots of gristle and inedible bits. not a lot of flavor in the meat. it's worth coming back here though to explore some other menu items. it will be tough to beat la mediterannee  on fillmore, but i need a closer location for this kind of food.
stay tuned for an update soon.
author: Jeff W.

description: Just had a super falafel here and it was not good. The wrap was stale, the potatoes hard as a rock and the eggplant was just a skin. It felt like a left over food from a week ago. I used to love coming here but not any more. Bummer!
author: J C.

description: Best falafel in town, they are telling the truth. The falafel platter is 5 stars. The other food was not as good; the lamb shwarma was dry and rubbery. The service is very nice!
author: Carrie H.

description: In searching for a meditteranean restaurant nearby, this place came up with 4 stars. It had to ok, right? I ordered the falafel, shawerma, hummus, kibbe, and tabboule salad. I tried a couple of bites of each item but I finally gave up and threw everything in the trash. Huge disappointment!!! It wasn't even close. And with all due respect,  whoever wrote the good reviews had not tasted good meditteranean food before. I wouldn't eat their food again even if they paid me for it. Avoid at any cost.
author: Basil S.

description:
I hadn't been back since the last disappointing visit.  As a 20+ year customer I can tell you that the quality just is not there anymore since the move to expand to so many locations.  
The Falafel used to be light and airy with flecks of parsley and an aroma that just made you smile.  I bought 6 this evening, came home ate half of one and put the rest in the compost bin.  These were heavy, the inside was a gooey paste and they smelled as though the oil hasn't been changed in ages.  
As much as I wanted to give the new owners the benefit of the doubt from my visit several month ago, the reality that the quality and taste that Sunrise Deli was known for is no more.
This is a real shame, but alas it is the norm of the day - profit before all else.
Terrible food.  No I will not be back.
author: Catania G.

description:
Ok, I *love* middle-eastern food, and Sunrise has the best falafel in the city (and possibly in life). Not oily. Tastes like it is baked. This is the REAL DEAL. And food here is super cheap! I don't know how they do it. Owners are super friendly. Family owned place.

I would recommend getting take out. It's not the best place to dine-in.
author: Sahana U.

description:
This place has the BESTEST falafel I've ever had in my short life. I've never been a fan of falafel until I've been here. I'm filipino folks so I wasn't 100% familiar with this food to begin with and sadly the falafel I've tried before in college and other places, tasted like cardboard crumbled up in your mouth.

And then I came here. I can seriously eat their falafel like popcorn or potato chips. It's not only so crispy, but the texture inside is moist, consistent and super TASTY!!!  Fresh! And not just their falafel is great, but the hummus, the ring bread, the olives, the tibouli....ALL if it. You cannot go wrong with anything on their menu.

Plus you know it's good when all my husband's Arab & Greek friends (who own their own restaurants/stores in SF) all come here and have been coming here. I live in Hawaii now but seriously, whenever I go back home I always make it a point  to come here and get my 1/2 dozen falafel fix. I have yet to find a better falafel than this place. Period.

Pros:
-FALAFEL!!!!!!
-Cheap
-Convenient to get to on Irving/21st
-Fresh, great quality  

Cons:
-Parking on Irving can be tricky especially on weekends.
-There really isn't any ambiance here, and just few tables to sit. Really, you don't see many folks eating in here, just take it to go. 
-They're only in SF and on Irving!!! Boooohooo!!!
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Their veggie combo plate tastes like heaven. For $9, you get an assortment of rice, lentils, hummus, tabouli, falafels, dolma, and pita bread. It's enough to fill anyone up, and while their hummus can't really stand up to anything from Dearborn, MI, their falafel kicks ass.
author: Danny C.

description: I come here just for the falafel.  Fried goodness in a ball.  I asked them if I could get a fresh batch of falafel and they made it for me on the spot.  Nothing beats a freshly made falafel.  Their other menu items look interesting and its not really pricey.
author: Rob C.

description:
Quite underwhelming lamb sharwarma.  Didn't have much taste of lamb--maybe tough sole of boot.  Sorry for defecting (today only because of location) Truly Med--I'll be back soon.

 I'd go back for the falafel though.
author: benwa h.

description: This place is so delicious and the atmosphere is just right. I'm tired of ultra stylish SF expensive bla bla. The falafel and salads are on point.
author: M L.

description:
I came here in the middle of the afternoon and there was only one person in line before me. I placed my order and sat patiently while I waited for my food. Thirty minutes later they finally told me my food was ready. They forgot part of my order. I sat there and waited another ten minutes while they finally finished my food. People who arrived after me got their food and left first. The rest of my order was cold. The food was not that good and I wasted so much time I was infuriated by the time I left. Also, the falafel was so salty that I couldn't even finish a whole one. By the time I finally got to eat, I didn't really enjoy it because the food was salty and cold and also because I was mad.

The owner did ask if I wanted some dessert for free but I was so angry that i didn't even want free dessert and wanted to hurry up and get home and eat my food because I was starving. It probably would have taken them another hour just to pack up dessert. It was also uncomfortable to ask me if I want anything for free - like I was asking for hand outs. They should have just put it in my bag.

If the place was super busy or hectic I would have understood if they forgot but I was one of four people. The food isn't good enough to ensure the terrible service.
author: Don L.

description:
The place looks like a hole-in-the-wall, so I was excited when I came in. I really love shawarmas but it was just okay here. The flavor wasn't as strong and there wasn't that much meat in my plate. I suppose what they're really known for is the falafel, but I'm not a huge fan of that dish, so I opted for the shawarma. My friend ordered the falafel and she really enjoyed her plate.

Prices here were decent. It just wasn't special to me, but it was still good and filled me up. The staff seemed friendly but I recommend taking out, the place isn't that great looking.
author: Ivy L.

description: Seriously amazing food, great POLITE service, and inexpensive! highle recommend if you are in the sunset district, TRY THIS PLACE!
author: Giovanni M.

description:
Falafels are bomb, crispy on the outside, fluffy on the inside.

I give it a 5 star, because of their customer service. The owner was closing, but I told him I had driven far to get here, he then opened his door to serve me. Not many restaurants do that...
author: Justin R.

description:
Be wary of their food handling practices.  The gentleman who prepared my falafel had just finished handling money (no gloves).  He was not pleased when I asked him to wash his hands.  But I would have been far less pleased with an upset stomach.  

The sandwich was decent but by no means outstandiong.
author: Leon R.

description:
Fall 2012......the season I fell in love with Sunrise Deli's avocado falafel sandwich. The food truck makes an appearance to SF State's campus every once in a while and the only reason I tried it was because it was the only food truck without a line, which I still don't understand to this day because this fucking falafel sandwich is the most incredible thing I've ever tasted. It comes with pickled cabbage, falafel, avocado, lettuce, tomato, and hummus. I like to get mine in a pita wrap or lavash wrap rather than the pita pocket. It'll look more like a falafel burrito and it's significantly less messy. 

The food truck isn't always in the most convenient places for me to get to, so I usually go to the location on Irving or 2nd. I prefer the Irving location because it looks a lot more like a deli and the lady who runs it is always very nice. It's usually pretty empty when I go there (around 7pm) so I just have my food there. Plus they have free Wifi and I'll take that over fighting for a chair at the Starbucks any day. 

I wish their baklava wasn't so pricey, but DAMN. It's definitely in my top 3 places to get baklava.
author: Maegan T.

description: I'm not a food expert, but I eat a lot of meditterean in SF and this place has the best falafel I've had. Super cheap, walk up counter, and staff is friendly. Again, falafel and the food in general is incredible.
author: Mike C.

description:
Mixed feelings about this place.

Went down to Irving St. initially because my bf and I wanted some super cheap sushi from Let's Roll along with 99¢ milk tea from Teaway. We ended up parking in front of this place and noticed the sign on the window that says "follow our truck, best falafel in town etc." so I decided to whip out my trusty yelp app and check out their reviews. Reviews were almost 5 stars so we decided to check it out.

Walked in, looked at the menu and immediately noticed the avocado falafel pita sandwich.. I love avocado and was excited to take the first bite but unfortunately that fantasy was short-lived because they said that their avocados were not good enough to be served which is a good sign of customer service even though that was the only thing that looked appealing :(

I was then forced to pick something else and with the help of my bf, picked the falafel plate. I helped my bf pick the lamb schawarma plate which smelled really good...

Pros: falafel IS verry good! I love it. Also, in the front there is this case of sweets.. we got the pistachio baklava (which is TO DIE for! love the flaky-ness) and this chocolate almond crunch thingie which was also heaven. 

Cons: the lamb schawarma plate was not as good as it smelled.. I never tasted shawarma before and had no idea what I was getting myself into but evidently schawarma is a little SWEET and I hate SWEET meat! On top of that, the lamb was so dry I had a really hard time swallowing it... I almost choked at one point. Their hummus taste like any other kind of hummus except they put some purple sour steak fry looking things in it, which killed it for me. 

The thing that disappointed me the most was their tahini sauce.. I was expecting it to be thick and creamy because to me, that's always the best part of Mediterranean food! Sunrise deli's version of tahini sauce is EXTREMELY watery and sour and bitter all at the same time.. the taste echoed through my nostrils like wasabi.

They also have this chili sauce which is noticeably filled with chili seeds so when I took a spoonful and put it directly into my mouth, I was expecting it to be so hot that my eardrums would burn but it was not even close.

If I ever do come back it would be ONLY for the falafel, baklava and other sweets..
author: Sarah E.

description:
You know what I hate? Businesses that partake in deals such as Groupon and then act all pissy and annoyed when customers come in to use it. Don't participate in it if you don't want customers walking in with it!!

I came here on a saturday afternoon really wanting to try their avocado falafel after reading reviews and getting a groupon deal. I walked in and the guy taking orders asks me nicely what I want. I tell him that I have a groupon deal and he immediately starts becoming pissy and annoyed. Excuse me, stop putting your deli on groupon if you don't like it. So I pull up the deal on my phone since I didn't print it and he keeps asking for the barcode. I show him that my phone says to show that page to the business owner and he says that I can't use the deal because I'm not showing him what he needs. I tell him Fine and i just walk out and he decides to be nice to me again as I am walking out.

I would have probably decided to go home, print out my deal, and come back another day if it wasn't for his bad attitude. Instead, I'll look elsewhere for my falafels and i'll change my groupon deal to another place. 

I hate bad customer service.
author: Syd T.

description: You can't go wrong with this place. I have been to many countries in the Middle East so I know what I am talking about. The falafel is exactly how it should be. It's nice and crispy and the falafel sand which is great. It's smothered with hummus and eggplant and a whole bunch of other stuff.
author: Ddc C.

description: Wow hot falafel guy wearin raw denim and a man bun. The best falafel I've ever had, the yung avocado pita sandwhich is it.
author: Christina E.

description: Yeah, the falafel is unquestionably great but they don't seem to give a goddamn about regular bizniz hours. Advertised as open 'til nine but we got there at 7:45 and it was closed up tight & dark. Ah well, coulda' been anything. Anyway, yeah the falafel's the thing and now it's closer to home with the Haight shop. The chicken shwarma is real good, too.
author: Phillip M.

description: Falafel from here is gooood. Real crunchy on the outside and moist on the inside. Just buy a dozen of em
author: Kayhan K.

description:
If you want good reviews, look at any number of them for details.  Mine is specific to CATERING.

We were looking for someone to cater a bday party in the park (30-40 ppl).  Wanted something easy, finger friendly, etc, and have always liked the sandwiches here so thought we've give them a try.  My biggest concern was that the falafels either wouldn't be fresh when we picked them up, or that they'd get old/dried out by the time we got set up and guests arrived.  

Now I can't speak for all times of the day or days of the week but we picked everything up at 11am on a Saturday.  When I got there, everything was wrapped up and ready to go and we proceeded to load the car (we got 3 platters).  As we finish, I pay and turn to leave and they say, "Wait, falafel's almost ready!".  In other words, they were frying it up fresh on the spot for me!  Not only did the falafel stay fresh and was warm by the time we served everything 30+ minutes later, but EVERYONE at the party was commenting on them and they were the first thing to go.  Definitely the best falafel I can remember having.

My ONLY "complaint" is that when I called the day before to confirm my order and asked if they delivered, they said they did, but it cost $20!!  (in comparison, when I'd called another place, they were only going to charge $3).  Trying to save money I opted for picking it up.  Day of I decided, "Ehh, my sanity's worth $20 not to have to drive over there, etc" and called to add the delivery (this was at least 1-2 hours before) and by then delivery wasn't available so I had to pick it up anyway.  Again, not a big deal at all but I did feel the charge, had I paid it, was quite steep (and as a side note, I could've sworn there was some sort of private food delivery company for things just like this...couldn't find anything online that did so.  Would've probably been half as much if I'd just called a cab to come get the food and bring it to me...).

Overall, party was great, food was phenomenal (and as one more aside, they gave me as many forks, spoons, and napkins as we needed, which was very nice) and yes, the owner was extremely nice and responsive.

Go Sunrise!
author: David M.

description:
Why would I have ever taken a star away from this heavenly falafel establishment?

FIVE STARS FOR YOU, SUNSET DELI!
author: Ang F.

description:
The Felafel is pretty good. But the Babaganoush and Hummus are the best in the Bay Area. And believe me I've tried a lot of different places in the past 22 years. It's always fresh and moist. Buy some pita bread (at $2.00 a bag that's a bargain!) to toast and cut into strips to eat the BBG and Hummus with.
Their homemade Baklava is pretty good too!
author: Andrew S.

description:
I'm currently eating their Chicken Shawarma. I remember it was my first year high school, the last time I ate shawarma. Woah! After each bite, makes me remember my high school times. I love it!

Fantastic food! Deducted one star for fantastic ambiance. The place need some remodeling and some cleaning.
author: Calvin Nicholei L.

description:
This minor update is for the Sunrise Deli truck that I had half a dozen falafel balls from at the SoMa StrEat Truck stop. 

They're damn good...very crispy, but not overly cooked, and perfect with the side of hummus.  Oasis may have met its match.
author: Jeff N.

description: Consistently tasty food - my favorite, of course, being the well-seasoned falafel. The super falafel sandwich is fantastic - and a LOT of food! It's filling and delicious, a good choice if you're in the mood for something different from the usual falafel sandwich in pita bread. I've been coming here for several years now; it's a great low-key place, and you can't go wrong with the falafel!
author: Delia Z.

description: This spot is well known so there's isn't that much to say... other than: popping in for a 75¢ single falafel or a five sack is fun. I can be somewhat noncommittal with food / meals & love walking & talking & eating. Thus this is a prime example of the city life where you can buy some falafel & go your way. And is it "The Best Falafel EVER" as their taglines read? Likely around here, yeah. I'd love to meet its match though. Be aware that if you leave the falafel lying around in your apartment it begins to permeate the environment full tilt. Maybe it's like the 25¢ giant bubble gum ball machines as a kid, but this is definitely the adult equivalent of that type of pop in meal.
author: Jon A.

description:
Mmm! I work on Irving Street, and not a day goes by when I am not tempted by the thought of scarfing down an avocado falafel on my lunch break. So good!

They really have the falafel recipe down. These little crunchy balls of yum synchronize fantastically with their own tahini and hummus. The sauces get drippy but who wouldn't lick their fingers after tasting this?! It's filling and it's got the perfect mix of creamy, crunchy, and chewy.

I really like this place but it is a hole in the wall so keep your eyes peeled for it. Also, if you happen to see me there, buy me lunch.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Great falafels and good kufta kabab. Plate presentation was very colorful and a feast for eyes. I not certain about making my own gyros, but I ended up asking for some of the some additional condiments such as humus to add to it as there was no yogurt...they were very happy to oblige and quite friendly. Walnut baklava was very good. Pistachio baklava had whole as opposed to crushed nuts, which i have not run into before and I felt that the nuts were too chewy like this, definitely like walnut variety better.

Falafels were the best I have tasted since a trip to Istanbul.
author: Michael H.

description: I had the Super Falafel with Hummus, Eggplant, Potatoes, Lettuce, Tomatoes, Tahini Sauce, served in lavish bread.  The falafel was excellent. Crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside.   Their hummus was also great.  Creamy and tangy.  I'm so glad there is a place in the Sunset to satisfy my falafel cravings.
author: Gordon A.

description: Had a shawarma plate. The meat had little flavor and was extremely tough and chewy. Maybe I should have had the falafel so I would be able to say better things about this place. But for now, it's a two-star joint.
author: Jacob G.

description:
If your fussy about tidiness you will not like this place.

But, if like me, you love little hole in the wall restaurants with delicious, inexpensive and fresh food, this place is a gem.

The food, and I am a middle eastern food nut, is wonderful and fresh.

The only reason I don't give it five stars is it is pretty grimy, and I'm a guy so I'm not terribly fussy about such things.  But as an architect, because of the griminess, the place doesn't make a great first impression when you walk in and look around.   Nor is the staff there very engaging.

But man is the food delicious and inexpensive.

In short, highly recommended.
author: Michael C.

description:
My friend and I came here because he is absolutely in loveee with their falafel. Not being a falafel lover myself, I opted for the shawarma, so this review is purely for that. NOT a judgment on their falafel in any way, because from what I heard, it's pretty dang tasty. 

After spending the summer in Europe, I'm kind of a Shawarma freak/nazi. I've been trying place after place in the city, looking for something that will measure up. I want that giant vertical spit of tender, juicy meat, sizzling as it turns, glistening with fat, and I want it fresh cut off the roaster. I want a fluffy pita pocket overflowing with tabouleh and onions and hummus. 

This shawarma was not that. It wasn't terrible, but there was a lot to be missed. I get it, I have high expectations, but this place didn't really come close to meeting them. It was good in its own, unique way. The meat was well marinated and the pickled cabbage added a little something, but that's about it. The pita pocket was your typical, store bought dense, dry pita and the meat, although decently flavorful was a little dry. Not a bad pita pocket, by any means, just not at all what I wanted. 

So, yup, I'm a shawarma snob, but this place was just ehh. It was probably the best shawarma I've had here back in the states, but I'm still on the hunt. It's nice to see that it is mom and pop owned, though, and I'm sure the falafels are delicious because they looked fresh and smelled amazing.
author: Michelle Q.

description: Sooo yummy. I just had a regular falafel pita sandwich and it melted in my mouth. Excellent quality that I will be back for over and over again.
author: Paul B.

description: Don't serve me reheated falafel. Fry it fresh it takes 2 minutes.
author: Andrew O.

description: My friend got an awesome deal: $1 for $10 worth of food.  We ordered a bunch of falafels a tomato and cucumber salad, and some hummus.  The falafels were definitely fresh and made to order.  Salad was very good and went well with some pitas and hummus.  Best in SF?  I don't know, but definitely worth coming back to.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Delicious food & the owner is super nice.

 My friend was taking a long time to order since he had never tried this type of food before, so the owner gave him a sample of some falafel and hummus! 

Soo nice.
author: Christina X.

description:
i used to go here for falafel (spelled that way on their menu board) but this last time (just a couple of days ago) i went there and got half a doz. 

i was surprised and disappointed to find them virtually tasteless!  they used to have a hint of cumin in them (as others i have tasted elsewhere but this time,  nothing, nada.  

guess i wont be going back there until they change it back to the original.
author: dee c.

description: Management has changed I guess... very rude people... lost it's charm! Falafal is good but with host like the new guys.. I would rather not eat that falafel! never going back!
author: Neetha V.

description: I work right next to the downtown location on 2nd street, and I've eaten there a lot during the past year and a half. Still the best falafel in town. Super falafel is the way to go, I feel, although I have been known to just order a bag of falafel and some hummus and pita.
author: Ben G.

description: Was really craving Falafel and this place got good reviews and was close, so I gave it a looksie. I was pleasantly surprised because I got the avocado falafel sandwich to go (and was running a bit late) which usually means the sandwich will be soggy by the time you get it but my sandwich actually still held quite well (which indicates good pita to me). It tastes like they use a pickled cabbage which is amazing, and the falafel itself was reallllly tasty (almost tasted like it was cooked in meat oil to me but that was just me and I don't think they do). The cons were that I wish the falafel and the veggies were more well mixed together, also the hummus was little overpoweringly lemony (or I guess citric-acidy). Anyway I'm a fan and will be back for more!
author: Serena C.

description:
I had a falafel plate and loved it. It's right around the corner of my friend's house. Good to know there is one near work and one in Berkeley, too!
I'll definitely come back.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Tried this place a month ago and it was a great place for a Falafel. As we walked in the owners were welcoming. The atmosphere is definitely deli-esque but a chill atmosphere to eat in - you do have the option of taking your delicious Falafel to-go of course. 

As for the Falafel, I'm pretty biased to the Falafels that I munch on back home but this was an overall great wrap. I love that the include both hummus and tahini sauce into their wrap. I should have asked for a little bit of hot sauce to go with it but I could tell that the Falafel was well made - not like some of the microwavable tasting stuff I have tried at other places.

I'd love to come back to this place and try something else on their menu!
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
I had the falafel plate and it was delicious; it's a platter with falafel on a bed of lettuce with a huge heaping of both hummus and tahini. Plus it comes with pita. Delicious and also kind of light, which was surprising (meaning that it didn't feel dense). It was fresh and oh so tasty especially with the blend of hummus and tahini.

My BF had the kabob plate and I ended up snagging his leftovers. The rice with lentils is perfectly season and even the chicken he had with it was still moist and tender. It blended very well with the hummus. This is a great spot with great service so I'd highly recommend it, of course.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Middle Eastern food in the middle of the Asian part of Irving??  Hmmm...I just had to check it out for myself.  

I walked in and was greeted by two spits of meat, and a deli case full of appetizing salads and dips.  It took a while for me to decide what I wanted.  Everything sounded really good.  I went with the lamb shawarma( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/6TalxzSIOllPRrSCINF37w/l ) and a 1/2 pint of the cucumber and tomato salad( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/nXlrYri6pckfyhJSi_D3tg/l ).  

The shawarma was deeeelish!  The lamb was nice and tender, and the tahini sauce gave it an extra burst of flavor.  All the ingredients were really fresh...crispy lettuce and red, juicy tomatoes.  The cucumber and tomato salad was very tasty.  It complemented my shawarma very well.

I saw a batch of freshly fried falafels, and they look really good.  But I didn't get one since I ordered the salad.  Their menu says they're "The Best Falafel in Town!"  I'll have to come back and see if they really are the best!
author: Patra I.

description:
Awesome Mediterranean food!  I am a big big connoisseur of Mediterranean food (particularly Lebanese), and the food was much better than my expectations.  You walk into what looks like just another "mom-and-pop shop" deli with about 5 tables past the deli counter and some fairly crude hand-written notes under pictures of various dishes.  

I was expecting just "average deli food" and was pleasantly surprised to find a well-portioned plate of kabob meat, hummus and tabbouleh (thats what I ordered of course) and a plate of "authentic" pita (it had the look, feel and texture of a leavened wheat pita - something new for me) - all for about $11 + tax. Not too shabby.  Daddy like.

It was my first visit, and I will need to frequent this place more often before I can convince myself to give it 5 stars (and be able to sleep at night for doing so).  You gotta make these places earn that coveted 5-star right?  Well, Sunrise, keep up the good work ...
author: M P.

description:
3.5 Stars.  The falafels are good here but it was a little heavy/greasy for me.  The hummus was great and I'd definitely eat here again, but it's a bit of a hike for me to get to.  

If you're close by, definitely stop by.  But I'm still on the hunt for the best falafels in SanFran.
author: S R.

description: Vegetarian Combo!! Comes with pretty much ALL the sides, falafel and dolmas!! Small for yourself or large if you plan to share. Get extra falafel because those are amaze balls-- literally amazing balls. I'm not going to give myself any credibility for how I know that this is an authentic falafel or the hummus or other sides are made the "proper" way... But the food is so good!! Come here you must.
author: Rachelle F.

description:
This is a pretty good Middle Eastern Restaurant in the Sunset.
The Restaurant itself isn't much to look at, but the food is good.

The falafels were good, but not the best in the city (The Mission has better Falafel).

Owner runs the place and is very friendly, they have a few unique dishes which you can't find at every middle eastern restaurant.
author: Ayall S.

description:
Dear falafel, I love you. 

Seriously, these are hands down the best I've eaten in my life. If you go, definitely get the falafel topped with avocado. Sooooo good!
author: Shachi B.

description: I absolutely love falafel. As a vegetarian, I find it to be sort of the perfect food. So I have it everywhere I can, and I'm constantly amazed by the variety in quality you can find. Some places are tasteless or coarse, some are mushy or hard. But in the end, I have no doubts: Sunrise deli has the best falafel I've found in the United States. There's no competition in San Francisco. Crispy on the outside, rich in flavor but not in fat. And, you know, they make a pretty good sandwich too. Also, the mujadra is incredible. The meat is probably tasty as well, although I wouldn't know anything about that. But if you're looking for falafel, this is the place to go.
author: Sam G.

description:
I loved this place. Completely unapologetic about the lack of style, and truly good food. The Pita sandwiches are to die for. The Falafel, Divine. I had eaten this places food three times before I actually went there. Every time had been at a party where some one had ordered a falafel platter or a large order of Lamb. When I finally went in I was both blown away and disappointed.

I have to say now I am a Chef Professionally, and I can spot day old veggies when I see them. The tomato and cucumber salad was at least a day old. This was rather disappointing, but the bad salad was more than made up for by the Pita sandwich. Sweet lord, was it good. I highly suggest any of the kebab sandwiches.
author: Thomas E.

description:
I ordered shwarma from this place. Portion was so smoll, it was cupple of peaces of dry, cold  meat and all the rest vegetable .
It's look like portion for baby for $7.04
It's to expensive for this kind appetizer .
author: Alex K.

description: Wow. I've been coming to this place since they  opened,  and the only complaint I ever had about them was that they put too much lemon in their hummus. But I have to say that I just went in to get a half dozen falafel and a few other items,  and was treated like I smelled. Maybe it's the big Chamsa, around my neck,   who knows, but I  was super stoked when I realized they were out of felafel and needed to make more. I was excited that I'd get some fresh ones woo hoo! However my mood was quickly dampened by the Crap way I was treated.  Someone mentions that perhaps the place has changed owners, this entirely possible because the folks that used to work there were super friendly, middle East stylee. I wish that I could report differently. The felafel are really good as usual, but I had to pay for them with humiliation. So sad.
author: roz A.

description:
To go from the strict meaning behind the stars, "meh, I've experienced better." While here, we ordered two wraps and the baba ganoush. While nothing was horrible, bland summed up the experience as a whole.

First off, the baba ganoush was surprisingly lacking in flavor. It just left no impression at all, with the most memorable aspect being the olives included as its not something we had seen before for baba ganoush.

For the wraps, they were so-so. The meat didn't feel as fresh as it could have, and didn't sit with our stomachs all that well. On the plus side, at least the veggies were fresh, although the wrap didn't have the best ratio of the ingredients.

 Overall, it wasn't horrible or anything, but we left saying wouldn't be back, which was a shame as we would have loved a local place to get our wrap fix...
author: Sami R.

description:
I often come here for the super falafel and for the avocado falafel.  It's the best Middle Eastern food that one can get in the Outer Sunset area.  It definitely beats driving down to the mission for something better.

I do think the prices can be little cheaper, or they can be more generous with the amount that you get.  They've also forgot to put avocado in my falafel few times (c'mon son!) but overall i'm satisfied with my experience.
author: yusai g.

description:
In the nearly 7 years of regularly going to Sunrise Deli, I have never had anything less than a good meal. 

Their falafel is great. Crunchy exterior, moist interior, made right before your eyes.

Their shawarma is delicious, flavorful, and tender. 

I would recommend this place for anyone with a casual desire for Mediterranean food, a good bite, or for catering for a small party. 

Their staff is always helpful and responsive to requests. 

Although their menu contains only the standard fare, everything on it is great, from the meat dishes, to the sides, to the wraps and sandwiches.

This place is great.
author: Alejandro V.

description:
One hot falafel.

Fresh out of the fryer.

Mouthgasm.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: It was my first time on this place. I was looking for a good Mediterranean place for dinner. So I found this on Yelp and saw the ratings and distance. The Kufta plate was alright, but they gave me spoiled yogurt cucumber salad. I don't know if it has been sitting there for a while, or the temperature in the refrigerated counter is off. But please double check your salads. Good thing I caught it right away, but too bad that I was already home when I did.
author: Eva L.

description: The dozen falafel are a great deal, so we end up getting them a couple of times a month. Compared to other Mediterranean places in the neighborhood, which all seem to give us falafel that are still half-frozen, it is a gem.The Turkish Delight is also surprisingly good. There are lots of vegetarian options on the menu, service is business-like, and there is limited seating.
author: D E A.

description:
"What's Kufta?"
Ground up lamb with garlic...(he explains more)

"Which one do you like more: Chicken, Shawarma or Kufta?"
Lamb and Beef is good, says Deli man.

"OK I'LL TAKE THE KUFTA!!!"
Ok. What sides do you want?

"Oh. Erm... (I point) I want this thing with the green stuff" (Not sure why I spoke like a child, I was referring to the yogurt cucumbers)

silence.....

"Oh. Wait. No. I want the veggies and that wrapped thing" (The stuffed grape leaves)
Do you know what's inside that?

"Uhhh. I ate it before. I liked it!" 
Oh well it's grape leaves... (he gives me a thorough explanation but I'm kind of spacey and hungry for dinner)

"Cool. Thanks. Um I ALSO WANT A BAKLAVA!!"
(man looks taken aback that I pronounced it correctly, despite my apparent ignorance with the other foods)


Food review: I've tried the vegetarian plate and the kufta plate. This is a new gem I've found despite living almost a year in this area. Both were really delicious, and contain the right combination of flavors and textures. Not too dry, not too soggy. 

Plus the man working there was nice enough to explain things to me even though I was clearly uncultured that day :P. It's more of a take-out place.. though I wonder if anyone eats here during lunchtime...
author: Jenn L.

description:
Love this place! Even having moved out of the country, every time I fly in through SFO will stop here for food. 

Pros: everything
-fast service
-BEST food
-prices are fair
-variety is great
-consistent flavors
-take away options, and the food is great re-heated
-You buy tons of food and take it to go (or call ahead is I'm sure preferred)

Cons: bathroom, plan to go before you arrive, they have never remodeled it. (Although I did see a a full-size goat body being prepared once on the way to the bathroom that was pretty rad haha)
author: Meg R.

description:
When my mother visits, she makes a point of consuming as many falafels as possible, because where she lives, there is literally no place to purchase such a delicious Middle Eastern delicacy.  On her most recent trip to visit me, she decided to do some comparison-tasting and decided that this was her favorite falafel.  I'm inclined to agree with her assessment.

You might be wondering, how does someone who's allergic to garlic and raw chickpeas ever wind up tasting a falafel??!!!  It makes no bloody sense!!!

You're right, it doesn't.  I will admit, though, to stealing the ocassional naughty, absolutely irresistable bite, savoring the taste of the illicit goodness, knowing all too well that my intestines will chastize me later for this infraction...

Dare I say, it's worth it?

The falafel comes in a pita, which is how it should arrive...while other restaurants might attempt to deliver their falafel in lavash, which might be more stable as far as holding the wrap together but offers an imbalance of too much bread, Sunrise Deli offers the falafel the way it was intended:  the focus is the falafel, not the bread around it.  

Now, if you're looking for a glamourous environment, you won't find it here.  This is a place you go to pick up your meal to go, or to devour hastily at one of their very basic tables and chairs while staring at their shelves of groceries and fridges of cold beverages.  The word to think here is "casual".  But if what you're seeking is inexpensive, good food of the Middle Eastern variety, assembled and delivered to your waiting hands quickly, this is definitely one not to be missed!
author: Amy L.

description: Got food poisoning from this place! First time I had their food trucker I was already iffy about if I should get it again.. Their cook had an open sore on his hand and was handling the food. The cashier with dirt (at least some brown stuff) under his fingernails was handling food. eww... Next time I went to the irving location and it looked fairly clean, yesterday then today after I ate their food I got food poisoning.. my stomach rejected all that unsanitary/cross contamination (apparently they don't handle their food properly... Ready to never eat falafels again....
author: Raymond H.

description:
In the past during my college years, this was one of the SF places to get some value priced middle eastern food, because the falafel and pita bread among other things were really cheap then.

I happened to be around the area 2 weekends ago so I decided to visit. The store front looks small, although the inside is spacious and deep (some tables available to dine inside). The owner has a stern look, but as soon as you show your intent to make a purchase you do get very friendly service. 

I placed an order for an avocado falafel for me, a super falafel for my brother, a bag of pita bread (half dozen pita), half pint of hummus, and a type of Baklava filled with sweet cheese. The total was around $25.

The menu includes many pita "sandwiches" (falafel, shawarma, kabob), dips/salads (hummus, babaghanoush, tahini, tabouli, chopped cucumber and tomato, olives, etc.), 4 plates (falafel, vegetarian, shawarma, & kabob), and assorted pastries. Drinks are available in the refrigerators in the back of the store.

While completing my order, the owner was correcting a worker to put "less ingredients", no more than a third of the avocado half into the falafel. When I finally was eating that falafel in my car, I found that only one half of the falafel had that little portion of avocado, the other half had none. **sad face**
The super falafel is wrapped in lavash bread and stuffed with french fries (yes, weird), so it's sturdy. On the other hand the falafel in pita bread should be consumed when you get it, otherwise it'll be a soggy mess soon after. I found a piece of stem in one of the falafel fried balls, but not a big deal. - Deducted a star for all that.

The hummus is somewhat watered down, so it could be described as creamy but still tasty. I normally expect hummus to have a thicker consistency. - Deducted one star.
The baklava was nice, similar to a flaky cheese danish.

Overall, in my opinion, it's no longer a value destination (prices are moderate) and this particular visit was just okay. I don't live around this area so I cannot give them points for convenient location.
author: Luis C.

description: Seriously the best falafel i've had in SF. It's a flavor party in your mouth. The hummus is sinfully delicious and the people that work there are so friendly!
author: Wanda M.

description: Their falafel is excellent and I realized I know the family that owns this place from college! what a small world!
author: Misha T.

description:
Found BUGS (plural) in my food!!!

Went back to complain and saw a roach in the corner of the store. Wouldn't give me my money back, just offered to make another wrap. No, just no.
author: Scott W.

description:
The falafel was my favorite part of the meal, we ordered a dozen to go because it was so good!

We also ordered the sarwa which was decent but there was just not enough flavor and the meat was a little too tough.

Very nice service though, and very helpful. Feel free to ask for help if you need it, they usually oblige to samples too!
author: Wilson T.

description: I had one of the best falafels i've ever had here.  Pistachio baklava is really good too.
author: Mike Y.

description:
After having Greek food last night at Kokkari, I woke up craving for a baklava so I went on Yelp to look for any nearby Mediterranean places. Load and behold, Sunrise Deli & Cafe was located right in my neighborhood. I always walked by when i am on Irving but I never actually ate there. 

So I walked my hungry self and met with the BF and we venture off for a falafel and baklava. We ended ordering a Lamb Kabob plate ($9.99) that  came with 2 sides (we chose cucumber & yogurt & cucumber & tomato salad) and pita breads to go. Boy, am i stuffed! The lamb was very tasty and juicy. i would definitely come back again and order their falafels. i think I'm going through a GREEK phase or something.

PS.  Have anyone know none of the workers doesn't wear gloves when handling the food? Especially since the main guy who handles money also touches the food too? *sigh* as much as i enjoyed my lunch i really hate it when food employees doesn't use gloves! Its really UNSANITARY. i don't want to get a BAD stomach ache. :(
author: Carol Y.

description: My first chicken shawarma, and it was just okay. My bf ordered the shawarma plate, which is served with hummus. The hummus was watery and too tangy for my taste.
author: Sophia B.

description: I ordered their lamb shwarma, and it was good but a little dry, it may taste better if you get their hummus and add some while eating. but i would definently recommend that you get their falafel. its amazing especially with their hummus.
author: James W.

description: All I have to say is FRESH! and BEST Fallafels in San Francisco! So good!
author: Karen T.

description:
Best Falafel i've had in the west.  Fluffy, flavorful and fresh.  Great hummous and baba gannoush. yummy pickled eggplant.  Reasonable price. Fast Service.  No Frills.  

That's really all there is for  me to say.  I love this place, although I haven't been here in a long time.  

5 stars 5 stars!
author: Vanessa L.

description: I can't speak for the other menu items, but DAMN these falafel are amazing! Each bite is perfect: the outside is incredibly crunchy and dotted with sesame seeds, which add a nice pop. Then you get to the inside, which is quite dense (there's not a lot of parsley) but still smooth and creamy. At 2.99 for a half dozen (you can even get them separate for .50 if you want), it's a totally affordable bit of heaven.
author: Clarice W.

description:
I've been craving falafels for so long and my craving almost sat too long in the backburner that I almost forgot about it. I went to Irving hoping to get frozen yogurt but the flavors were not appealing to me. I went back to my car disappointed but I look up and there was Sunrise Deli! 

For half a dozen falafels, it was $2.99 and I believe $4.99 for a dozen. I ate about 3 and started realizing how salty it was. I think it would have been better had I ordered a falafel sandwich so that all flavors would balance out. 

Very friendly service and plenty of seats!
author: Connie C.

description: I fell in love with their Baba Ghanouj, so I'm on my kick because of them.  It reminds me of the Three Little Bears story.  This is just right!  It is so right!  The fresh falafel just the icing on the cake!  They make it fresh.  It is so crunchy.
author: Helen L.

description: Incredible falafel. Everything else is great too, but wow the falafel is out of this world. Just get a dozen to go and life will suddenly seem better!
author: El B.

description:
When I was in Chicago I had a go-to place for my middle eastern fare. It was pretty easy since most of the ethnic restos are concentrated in neighborhoods. 

I was walking along Irving St and saw Sunrise Deli, I thought it was lost in this neighborhood dominated by Asian restos! I checked the ever trusty yelp and I saw not only awesome ratings but also the magic $ cheap eats symbol! 

I went in, ordered the falafels and a beef shawarma sandwich. The falafels were fantastic! Crispy but not dry at the same time had a nice flavor with every bite. However, the shawarma sandwich was just fair for me, the beef was a bit dry but still was seasoned very well. 

Their menu is not that extensive but good enough for a quick middle eastern fix.
author: Gordon O.

description:
I will hold off on giving them five stars, because I have only eaten there once and it could just be the Hungry Nursing Mother in me raving over and celebrating the falafel I had. (Lately I have been having way too many "this is so damn good!" moments.) 

Although it's not just the HNM that enjoyed the falafel, my husband who is not H, or N, or M, likes their food too. We both thought their deluxe falafel which has potatoes (!), eggplant(!), and pickled cabbage (!!) in it was super delicious. I love that the wrap has so many components, but it didn't end up being a mushy mess. You can still taste the individual ingredients and appreciate how they all come together nicely. And I really really like that the pickled cabbage replaces the onions you usually get in falafel wraps. 

Did I mention it was huge? That really helps, because HNM has been getting a little possessive over her food lately, and sharing is a difficult virtue.
author: Candice B.

description:
I have been coming to this place since I was little kid - My parents used to pick up falafel here before heading to picnics in GG park. After all these years, I think a change of ownership, and based on the expertise of my sophisticated Egyptian palette, this is still, hand's down, the best falafel in SF.  I am speaking of the falafel balls themselves - you can get dozens for a reasonable price and host a great party at home, providing all the fixings on the side.  I always ask them to make them right in front of me, and I drag that oily bag right back home, where it doesn't last long.

The service isn't what it used to be - owner seems a bit moody, but they get you what you need and as quickly as they can.  The parking sucks.  But, they have a number of great side dishes and they still make the sandwiches the old fashion way, in a fresh pita pocket.  Yum. You may buy fresh bread right there as well.  

Again, my vote for the best falafel in SF!  Enjoy.
author: N F.

description: Love to stop in here and get a falafel plate for lunch it is always so good and they are quick in preparing it too.... I especially love the cucumber tomato salad :) The falafels are always nice and light as well...
author: Michael W.

description:
All I know about this place is... it has the best falafel in the city!!  And it's cheap too.  

I love 'em....my friend took me here once, and we ate like 6...and then we ordered about two dozen more.

I'm going to have to go back for more food later.
author: Fannie S.

description:
This place is fantastic.  Nice little Falafel/ Shawarma hole in the wall I can eat for cheap and relatively quick.  Looks kind of dirty from the outside, but not too bad once I sat down and looked around a bit.  This place is also a bargain, as the gf and I can have an overly filling lunch for around $15.

I've been sticking to the Chicken Shawarma Pita Sandwich every time I go here, while the gf goes for the avocado falafel wrap.  Both are great.  I typically don't eat dark meat chicken, which is why I'm surprised I like the chicken shawarma so much.  They utilize a good combination of both white and dark meat (although I have at times encountered some pretty weird pieces).  They give hefty portions, packing whole pita's with chicken, tahini sauce, hummus, lettuce and tomatoes.  Avocado falafel is TWO pitas full of ripe avocado and crispy hot Falafel (drooool!)

We've also had sides of hummus and this lentil and rice dish.  They are OK; we've found just the two wraps to be way more than enough food to feed the both of us.

ONE CAUTION:  There's this squirt bottle of chili sauce on top of the counter near where they make the food.  Even though it looks like it's for public use, DO NOT try to go and take it to pour on your sandwich!  They will yell at you like you are Apu from Aladdin and you just picked up the sacred red jewel in the Cave of Wonders!  Instead, just ask for some of the chili sauce and they will be more than happy to give you
author: Timothy C.

description:
Sunrise has solid schwarmas/sandwiches at solid prices. ($5-7 for a pretty filling snack/meal) - though I prefer the thicker fluffy pita that gyros come in over the flat pocket bread that Sunrise has. Their sides (hummus, salads) are tasty as well, and they also have a display of Mediterranean sweets like baklava that are fairly priced ($1-2). But really, Sunrise's one-item winner/gem are DEFINITELY their falafels. 

Five star falafels. Aka AMAZING falafels. Aka the best falafel of your LIFE.

Okay, so my friends have recently been calling me out on my excessive tendency to exaggerate everything. See:

"He's really tall, he's like ten feet tall."
"TEN FEET TALL?"

"Dude, she's super short. She went up to like my ankles."
"YOUR ANKLES?"

"I ate a lot of chocolate today - like, a thousand M&Ms."
". . ."

So now that I'm hyper conscious of this (somewhat amusing) habit of mine, I'm going to attempt to legitimize my statement: if you find a falafel tastier and fluffier on the inside/crispy-crunchier on the outside anywhere in San Francisco, hit me up - and if I'm to be stood corrected, I'll buy you a drink.

. . . really, though, I'd be more likely to just buy you some falafels from Sunrise and make you see the error of your ways. :)
author: Betty W.

description:
The falafels are so yummy, you could buy it by the sack to just much on.  I don't know how them make them tast so good without any meat.  if everything vegitarian tasted that good, i think i could probably do it...but they don't, so i won't.

Cheap prices, but plenty of filling.  save room for the baklava though!
author: Jason Y.

description:
Visited the Sunrise deli & cafe today for lunch with my husband. The place is not much to look at but the food oh my god is just yummy!

We ordered 1 regular falafel sandwich and one falafel plate between the two of us. The total bill came upto $14 which is a reasonable price to pay. Both the dishes had tasty pickled vegetables and the falafel balls were huge, light & crispy.

My only grouse was the tahini that came with our falafel plate...it was too watery and didnt taste much like anything. Next time we will just get 2 sandwiches.

It's definitely worth the drive from San jose where I stay!
author: Bindi S.

description:
I love this place!  I stumbled upon it while visiting the neighborhood, and I write this review as I sit in the deli on my second visit.  The falafel is absolutely perfect.  Never over cooked and perfectly spiced.  Today I'm eating the the Avocado Falafel sandwich which is heaven in a pita.  Creamy and spicy at the same time.  

The people are friendly and welcoming.  I'll be eating her regularly!
author: Unemployed D.

description: This used to be the best place to get a falafel or any other simple mediterranean. I used to love the Kefta Kebab. Since reading that the place changed hands, I understand why its lost some of its lustre. I recently had a Kefta Kebab meal at the FiDi location and it was OK. It tasted like the tomato broth was poured from a can and the pita was somewhat fresh, but not really. I used a coupon so I got to pay $5 for $10 worth of grub, but still walked away dissatisfied. In fact, the taste in my mouth was so bad I walked down the street to grab a street taco from the nearby mexican place.
author: Rich M.

description:
Nestled in the bustling, densely-Asian streets of Irving, Sunrise Deli & Cafe was a surprising dinner suggestion.

The avocado falafel was the best falafel I'd had in awhile.  The falafels were light and moist, which I was not accustomed to.  The complementing fillings provided a fresh taste to the falafel.  

From experiences at other restaurants, I had come to the conclusion that all falafels offered a tasteless, drywall meal that sponged up all the moisture in my mouth. 

Although the falafels were moist, I still wanted more sauce in mine, and was lucky to be able to spoon some in from my friend who had ordered a falafel plate.

At around $6, Sunrise Deli is a viable option for a lighter meal.
author: Andrew M.

description:
INCREDIBLE FALLAFELS

They fry up fallafels all day long, sometimes to order, so most of the time they wont' be more than 30 minutes "old."  Crispy on the outside, moist and flavorful on the inside.

The schwarma plates are also delicious -- grilled lamb shaved off the cone, slapped on the plate with hummus and drizzled with Olive Oil. 

Warning -- seating is limited, so you might have to wait for a table.

Mmm, mmm good.
author: Rita S.

description: The falafel was really good here!! My friend and I shared the regular falafel, and eating half of it was pretty filling. I like that it wasn't too oily as well. Definitely worth the cheap price. :)
author: Emily L.

description:
How does this place have four stars? I'm actually angry about how awful my meal was. 
One star because they gave me extra pita and the falafel was decent, however it wasn't warm. The humus was runny and disgusting and they skimped on my tomatoes!?? I am very unhappy and will not eat here again.

I work a few blocks over and have always wanted to stop by and try the food and unfortunately I did. I ordered to go and when I got home I was greeted with a mess.The only reason I forced myself to eat it was because I was so so so very hungry; other than that I would have tossed my seven dollar rip off of a meal. I can honestly say I regret spending money here.

If you want a great meal do not go here, instead head a few blocks down to Park Gyros..that's what I should have done!!
author: Denise S.

description:
top 5 falafels i've had ever. (vs LA/NYC/TX/ISRAEL) 

seriously it's that good. and cheap too!

very informal over here but trust me the food is bomb.com

the pickled radishes and baba ghanouj / hummus / tabouli are all so delish.

drooling as i'm typing.
author: jaclyn g.

description: This is purely for the food truck parked at the Streatfood Park in Soma. MEDIOCRE. Definitely not the best, or even that warm, or that cheap. In fact, they shorted me a dollar when giving me my change, so that is my tip for them. My tip for YOU, dear reader, is to KEEP WALKING.
author: Ian G.

description:
I love the avocado falafel here! 

Last time I got the avocado falafel, the guy A serve it to me without the hummus. And I really love it. the Falafel was just the right crunchyness and fluffyiness if that makes sense. The 2nd time around, guy B served it to me with hummus. I feel the hummus is overpowering the flavor of falafel its not as good anymore. (or i'm just not a fan of hummus).  

I didn't really like the lamb falafel. I feel it was hard to chew. 

Would come back again to try the chicken falafel.
author: Michelle D.

description:
With the new campaign in San Francisco for Meatless Mondays, I've been determined to find yummy vegetarian dishes. (Sidenote: Eating vegetarian cuisines once a week can be great for your body and the environment! Google Meatless Monday for more information. No, they're not paying me. Just a regular ol' SF Hippie that loves the environment and eating right.)

"It is only 5 o'clock. Should I have dinner now?" I pondered. As I stood outside the door, a lady walked out of Sunrise Deli & Cafe and said "they have the BEST falafel in the city and why would a stranger lie to you?"

I was convinced. Having already heard great things about Sunrise, I decided to get a "regular falafel" to go. The falafel was so crispy and crunchy and all the ingredients were fresh and nothing was too dry.

What shocked me was, why didn't I know about this place earlier?! A GOOD falafel place in the middle of Chinatown II in San Francisco should've stuck out to me like a sore thumb.

BOTTOM LINE: Falafel is a great vegetarian dish that even a meat lover can enjoy. I will definitely be making frequent visits here :)
author: Angel N.

description:
So unpretentious and unsuspecting--in a deadly addictive kind of way. (Luckily it won't break the bank like some of my other restaurant infatuations...)

I was moving into my apartment near SFSU asa freshman and my dad wouldn't let me finish what I was doing without completing my culinary education with this place. We got lost seeing as he hadn't been years and couldn't find parking save for many many blocks away. 

Anyway, point being, we got there, the lights were fluorescent, the shelves were old, the menu was straightforward and the food came in a plastic basket, but the second you smell the falafel and see it smothered in cucumber, tomato and tzatziki, all jam packed into a pita, you know you're in for something astonishingly beautiful. 

And it was--it's easily my favorite falafel--not too bready, crispy, fresh, spicy, not too dry and just expertly complimented by all of it's vegetable and dairy friends. 

Thank you Sunrise for spoiling me rotten--I love you for it.
author: Ani D.

description:
1.) The rumors are true--- the falafel is truly the best I have ever had in my life. The density is perfect, and they are perfectly fluffy, crispy, a delicious  in every way!

2.) The sides are all delicious as well--- I love the cucumber tomato salad w/ onions, the fresh tabbouleh, hummus, tzazaki (totally misspelled, I know), rice pilaf, and dolmas. The items are all fresh and wonderful.

3.) The Shwarma is good, but I think if this place has a downside it might be the meat quality. The chicken shwarma was pretty dry and flavorless so I don't really get that. The chicken KABOB meat, however, is great. The lamb shwarma is pretty good too--- I often get the shwarma wrap or plate. the lamb is GOOD, but not great. It can be a bit tough, gamey, and gristly. I think better quality lamb/chicken would throw this place over the edge. 

So #1 and #2 are GREAT, and #3 is GOOD. It's not bad, but that is where they lack IMO. Overall, the place is good enough for me to give it 5-stars because it is the best Mediterranean deli I know.

PS. It's owned by Palestinians, and they distribute a newspaper there. The newspaper is nothing but 100% propaganda; every single article is anti-Israel and anti-U.S.A.     I don't think this newspaper helps their image much...
author: James M.

description:
Sunrise Deli has a good Falafel wrap. I had been to the Sunrise Deli downtown and I have to say, the downtown one was better. The falafel balls were a bit fresher and the Lavash did not get soggy like the one I had in the sunset. 

The addition of Hummus and the pickled turnips were awesome and the falafels had good flavors. It would have been much better if they had a spicy sauce to put on it. They did have a chili sauce to add but there was about 2 inches of oil at the top of the bottle.

They sell falafel by the dozen and half dozen. $4.50 for a dozen. It is a great deal and I think I am going to start buying falafel there. It is cheeper to get a dozen falafels than a falafel sandwich.
author: Peter V.

description: Took me 30 min to get 2 shawarma sandwiches. The meat was tough and had no flavor. Took a couple of bites and threw it away. Service was horrible and they gave me the last of there cut up lamb and chicken from the fridge and heated it up. Yumma's up on 8th Ave blows this place out of the water!
author: Zack K.

description: Best Falafel in the city.  Avocado Falafel spicy on Lavash is so good... finish with fresh baklava and enjoy the day!
author: A S.

description: Best falafel in town and even their lentil soup is very good. For some reason I liked this location better than the other ones...
author: VIORICA C.

description:
I've been looking for a falafel place in the city and I've finally found one. In my opinion, it doesn't really compare to the Falafel Drive-In in San Jose, but I take what I can get.

Here are things you should know:
1.) Order, sit, eat, then pay at the register.
2.) Everything is reasonable. The regular falafel was the perfect amount for me.
3.) Beware of the pita with a hole in it, it can get messy quick.
4.) Parkings a bit of a hassel simply because it's Irving.

I only wish there was sauce on top. When I first bit into it, it was a bit dry. But still delicious (and healthy!).
author: Jessica H.

description: I've been here at least 10 times and the falafel's are the best in town hands down.  Unfortunately the chicken shawarma and kebabs leave something more to be desired.  They have what I would consider "fresh" shawarma cooking on the spinning grill yet when you order it they grab old chicken shawarma from a container in the fridge.  Not sure why they don't cut fresh chicken rather than serve re-heated old chicken.   The plates turn into a soupy mess as they load, hummus, chicken, and rice over a bed of lettuce.  Stick with the falafel dishes.
author: Ronald Z.

description: seriously why can't i get over how ridiculously good the falafel is right after it comes out of the fryer ( which is how you often are served it here), and the chiecken kebab meat which is marinated and grilled to perfection... it's a real wow of a meal here for the money...the lamb is great and and sides are fantastic.  Chicken shawarma meat doesn't really taste good compared with the kabob meat, it's just not as good. why? don't know... but i still love the place.
author: Adam O.

description:
For as long as I have lived in the Sunset district, this place has been making good food. I think it has been through at least three owners in that time, but the food is consistently good.

The only dolmas I can eat are theirs - others are gross in comparison. I love the vegetarian plate - for the past few years they have been giving out extra veggies which is nice for those of us who are trying to cut back on their bread intake. The lamb shawarma plate is also tasty.
author: Audrey H.
