description: My parents brought me here in ~1986 (I would've been around 4 years old), and ever since, Sunrise Deli has defined what a good falafel should be: dark green-brown on the crispy outside, bright green and moist on the inside.  The flavor of their falafels simply has never been matched or bettered by any other falafel joint I've ever been too.  I would chalk this up to nostalgia on my part, but every other person I've ever brought over has agreed - there simply aren't better falafels to be found anywhere in California.
author: Huxley D.

description:
To be honest, the falafel balls were pretty good.  You can't eat just one. trust me. I had 12! They were Amazing. The lamb shawarma on the other hand was nothing spectacular. It was chewy, bland, and dry. I guess it was sitting on the vertical broiler a little too long. 

Overall, come here for the falafel balls. Even though the balls were premade before I got there, it was still good. Next time i'll try more on their menu.
author: Matt V.

description: Best falafel I've ever had! Inexpensive too! If I ever have a Tasha's favorite things party, this is going on the menu! They're just the right amount of fluffy and crispy, plus the gentleman makes them right there to order! Yum yum yum. Hummus is a little watery and they kinda short you on avocado on the falafel wrap, but honestly I'm still infatuated with the falafel. I'm gonna go get some now...haha.
author: Natasha V.

description: This place gets 5 stars for the falafel, 4 stars for everything else.  The falafel is perfectly crispy on the outside, and even though Truly Med is my go-to place for shawerma, their falafel cannot compare with Sunrise Deli.  The only downside is that most of the wraps are served in pita bread instead of lavash bread, and since they give you generous servings of hummus, it may leak through the flimsy pita bread and get messy.
author: Beatrice W.

description: Best falafel- this location beats the one on 2nd street. Their falafel comes fresh out of the fryer, super hot and crunchy on the outside, well seasoned and fluffy on the inside.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I've been going to Sunrise Deli for a long time. After trying many other falafel in different parts of the country, I think they have the best I've ever had. Many times we buy a dozen falafel, pita bread, tabouli, humus and baba ganoush, take it home and make sandwiches. The food is soooo good! 

Sometimes we get a wrap or sandwich and eat it there. Today we tried their deep fried kibbee. It was very good. I still prefer baked kibbee having grown up on it but do like their kibbee as well. 

They've also put some money into the interior. It's much nicer. This is one of our mediterraen food mainstays in San Francisco. It's always consistent.
author: Rachel M.

description: I found my favorite falafel shop in the outer sunset, better yet the city! The cooks/owners made sure the falafels were freshly made and even came with a spoon of hummus. I enjoyed the Chicken Kabob with Tabouli. Everything was exception and made with care. My meal with two falafel (75 cents each) came up to $16.00...which is not too bad for a good mediterranean meal in the most unlikely place.
author: Betty B.

description: I've only been here twice, but the service was so nice and the avocado falafel was awesome that I had to give 'em 5 starts.  Shame on me, I've lived in this neighborhood my whole life and only recently walked into their shop.  Glad I did.  Lovely service, yummy food.
author: A T.

description: Love this place been coming since I was little. For years the only place I would eat them because no others compared! Two dozen falafel's, a plate of hummus, and a cucumber tomato salad disappears in about a minute in front of my family!
author: Auji P.

description:
I've been to this spot a couple of times. 

I have to concur with other yelpers who are in the minority for this spot. It's good. Not great. 

And, it's kind of pricey. Almost 9 dollars for a small chicken shwarma plate. That being said, their hummus is delicious and so creamy. How do they get it like that!?
author: Dusty B.

description:
"Best Falafel in Town"

Alright... perhaps. The falafel itself is pretty darn good. But the fun stops there.

Boring, crappy packaged pita bread.
Bland, thin, runny hummus.
Gross tahini sauce.
"Hot" sauce has no flavor
Iceberg lettuce
And the falafel is NOT freshly fried!

There are much better places in town that deliver the full package.
author: Alex F.

description: The falafels are so good that every two weeks I go there and buy at least a dozen for my family and also the pita bread is the best. Now that they have a food truck they should come to CSUEB on Wednesdays and Thursdays.
author: Alex T.

description:
This is the best falafel in the city.  I haven't tried anything else since I haven't made it past the falafel, but when you make something better than anyone else in the city you deserve 5 stars.

The people who work here are awesomely nice too.  I always feel good about giving them my business and leaving a dollar in the tip jar.
author: Greg J.

description:
BEST FALAFEL IN THE CITY.

I don't need to say more.

oh except this...it's particularly delicious with avocado. MMMM-mmmm.
author: Alexandra A.

description:
mmm... i love their falafel! I'm a food fattie and can scoff down half a dozen before I even head home. ugh. i know so bad, but whatever.

I got the the pita sandwiches before.. it was ehh.. It just wasn't as good as I thought it would be.
author: Tina T.

description: This is probably my favorite place in the city to get my falafel fix. Their falafels are perfectly crispy and packed full of flavors with an interior that melts in your mouth but is still chewy and appeals to your mouthfeel. They are affordable and their tahini sauce is freaking delicious! I was introduced to this place by my boss in high school and have been hooked ever since. I always try to stop by to get a falafel sandwich or just a bag of falafels as a snack. Interior is a bit dingy with just a few tables, but the service is excellent and they also have a wide variety of shawarma, etc. Would definitely recommend to a friend.
author: Sannie L.

description:
After seeing the rating for this place, I must admit I was very disappointed. Since moving here from the east coast a few months back, I've been on a quest to find a place that offers good halal gyros/shawarma, and have been disappointed each and every time. My experience at Sunrise was no different. While I was ecstatic at the fact that I finally found a place that served their gyro in pita as opposed to Lavash (step your game up, SF!), the meat used was pretty iffy. The lamb/beef was far too chewy, and  didn't seem very fresh.

On the bright side, the falafel looked legit, and after reading some more reviews, seems to be the real draw for this place. I'll be back.
author: U K.

description:
Yummy falafels, above average hummus, and generous sized sandwiches, make this place a go to spot when I can't think of something else to eat. 

You can get 6 falafels and a hummus dipping sauce for less than 4 bucks, so that could be a yummy snack
author: Legal D.

description: I had just come back from Israel when I visited sunrise deli.  The falafel here is better than any I had in Israel. On the other hand the shwarma plate is forgettable (too much hummus). I'm excited to try the avocado falafel and the baclava in future visits.  P.S. The restaurant isn't Kosher but it's Halal.
author: Samuel P.

description: Best falafel in SF. They will fry it up fresh for you if you are ordering a reasonable amount and ask nicely.  Also the tomato and cucumber salad is delicious.
author: Molasses C.

description:
I couldn't wait to come back to sunrise and try some of the other offerings, since my falafel sandwich from last time was so damn good.

This time around I ordered a half dozen falafel, small side of baba ghanoush, and a small side of mujadarah. Total with tax was $9.83.

As it was last time, the service was friendly and quick. The owner is pretty friendly and so are his workers.

The falafel was hot out of the fryer and delicious. Crunchy outside with a smooth, almost creamy center full of tastiness. The mujadarah was excellent too and the abundance of sweet, caramelized onions on top made me wish I had ordered a large helping.

The baba ghanoush had gone south though. There was a definite sour and fermented taste to it. Yuck. So I asked the owner for hummus instead and he happily had it served up in no time. Unfortunately, I wasn't that fond of the hummus, as I've had much better elsewhere. The olive oil and the few pickles that came with the hummus were very good though.

My feeling is that this is an A1 place for a sandwich, order of falafel, or mujadarah. All are reasonably priced and well made. The sides of baba or hummus though are really too small to be worth the money, even if they were any good.

BTW- The falafel is NOT gluten free.
author: CrapulentMoose ..

description: im a big fan of M food, but after eating here i haven't eaten M food for more than 3 months. It was really that horrible. Ordered mega falafal wrap or something of that sort...it was just a mix of all left overs in the bread...yuk !
author: Foodlover L.

description: This is a review on their truck. Tried out a falafel wrap last weekend at SoMa StrEat Food Park. Damn, best effing falafel I've had in this city. Super crisp and fresh falafel. I haven't had Liba's truck, yet, which I hear is also damn good. But for now, this is at the top of my list. I had a wrap on Saturday, then stopped by again Sunday for another one. If I worked closer to the food park, I'd have another one again today.
author: Sophie P.

description: This place never fails me! I always get the same order - chicken kabob plate with baba ganoush and tabbouleh. Definitely use their hot sauce in a bottle with your food.  The food comes out fast and you don't have to pay until the end of your meal.
author: Mimi N.

description:
Ohh..man.What a joke of a place.

Went in today, since finding a Mediterranean food serving place in an all-Asian district is pretty rare. Anyways....Got it, ordered a lamb shwarma to go and,like a previous reviewer mentioned, the meat was sitting cut somewhere and the guy just threw it in an oven to warm it up a bit.REALLY ??? I wish I had read the other review before.Anyway,I was hungry so waited for it.I asked the guy if they put french fries in their shwarmas - I saw a plate with fries already made on the counter - and he said "no,but do you want any?". I said "yes". When he charged me, he added an extra $1 to my bill.When asked why, he said it was for the fries . WTF ? You take out the more expensive lamb meat of my meal and replace it with a cheaper filling but you still charge me more ? Anyways...the shwarma is small and skinny, the meat was disgusting ( cold,not seasoned,very chewy) and the hot sauce he provided on the side was 95% oil and the rest some pepper seeds.Gross ! I had to stop by a near by Vietnamese restaurant to borrow some real hot sauce to eat that crap.I felt like crap for the next few hours after eating this meal.I know why now....

Ohhh....as the place overall goes, I needed to use the bathroom while waiting for my meal to be prepared.I was told to go to the back,thus crossing the entire kitchen area.No sink in the bathroom,so you figure out how those guys who handle your food manage to keep everything clean in there.I mean, they need to go to the bathroom at least a few times/day while working there and with no sink in there, they`ll go back handling your food and who knows what else on their hands right in there.GROSS !

It didn`t look like a place that I`ll ever want to step foot in again. A good shwarma could be served at the Mediterranean on 16th St, from where I`d been eating for the last 20 yrs.Tastier,bigger and just $1 more.Well worth it !
author: Tony M.

description:
It never fails, when I walk past this place when I'm running errands, I can never resist popping in to get a little tasty Mediterranean Morsel, or an Arabic Amusement (of the palate, that is).

This is indeed the best falafel in town, hands down.  The best is when you wait for them to make a new batch, and they give them to you literally hot from their oily jacuzzi.  To get them fresh like this sometimes takes patience, while other times just takes a simple call to ask when they are making them next.  Either way, you are in for some hot, beany deliciousness.

The baklava here is certainly good, but nothing will ever top the absolutely divine baklava I had in Washington, D.C. at now-defunct Azuza (RIP).

Despite their tahini being a lad on the runny side (I like mine a bit more viscous), their lamb shawarma's are so good that I when I eat them, I quitely sing to myself the little-known Knack song, "Ma-ma-ma-mYY Shawarma!"
author: Thomas M.

description:
Falaaaafel MAAAAN 
Falaaaafel man
Doin the best a falafel man can!
He puts the balls in to FRYYY
what a wonderful guuuy!!!
I love that falafel MAAAAAN!
He takes a pita
that we want to EATA!  
Then put's the balls in the hummous
cause he knows were gonna LOVIT!
And when I take a bite
I know it tastes riiiight!!!
CAUSE HE'S THE FAAAALAAAAAFEEEEELLLLLL
MAAAAAAAAAAAAAANNNNNN!!


(It's a song.  I just made it up sort of.
No need to be awed.  My gift of song comes natural.  As does my love of balls.)
author: Starla D.

description: I've gotta tell you. This place is the real deal for authentic home made Middle Eastern food. How would I know? Well for starters, I'm Greek so I've been around a version of this  stuff all my life, (I still think my mom was the best at preparing some of these dishes. Isn't that typical? Heehee) and also I really do know and like some of these foods. Which brings me to the Falafel. What can I say about that? If you love Falafel like I do, then while eating the first bite of your first one, you will immediately know , this falafel is by far he best there is, anywhere. Why? Because of the taste of course! Not to mention the "crunch factor" (really important in all fried foods but especially in this one.) it's authentic taste has that essential pungency and perfect mixture of ingredients that will make you feel you stumbled on this authentic falafel stand somewhere in the Middle East. (These are the true roots of Sunrise Deli, the family is Palestinian, and they make the original falafel from the place of its origin.) Point being, this is the way Falafel should be done. The rest of their foods are great also, although ma would give them a run for their money on hummus, Baba Ghanouj (eggplant dip) and Tzatziki (yogurt garlic sauce). Try their gyros (shawarma in Arabic) and don't forget to buy their homemade sesame ring bread. Although you can eat in, I prefer to take everything home and feast. Although falafel is better eaten immediately on the spot as it gets soggy from the steam in the bag, wth, just eat it on the way home. The only minus I can think of is that this stuff ain't cheap, and for us raised on it, it makes us want to make it ourselves.(I got them on hummus, I think.) Also, I know they have other branches, but this is the original, the headquarters of the authentic taste. I haven't tried the other ones. So go on down and try the falafel. I'll bet you can't eat just one......
author: George F.

description: Disappointed in their service and food. I got Regular Falafel and Chicken Shawarma. Both tasted bland. Maybe it was old though I went 10:00am so it should have been just made fresh.  Hmm, I won't be back.
author: Ame M.

description:
*** Updated 12/20/09 ***

So who has the best falafel in the sunset?  Yumma's is closer to home, it's open later, it has real lighting & decor (plus a back garden), and the prices are just as low.  But that makes Sunrise Deli poised for a come-from-behind victory.  So I decided the only way to settle it was a winner-take-all, side-by-side falafel-off:  Sunrise's Super Falafel vs Yumma's Falafel Deluxe.  And judged strictly on the food, Sunrise is the winner.  The wraps are fluffier (but with a dense and spicy flavor) and the ingredients are well-packed (Yumma's tends to have all the sauce at one end).  And then there's SD's inspired decision to add potatoes--it may sound like too much starch, but their creamy softness beautifully contrasts the crunch of the falafel.  So yeah, biking the extra 14 blocks is totally worth it.
author: Wes M.

description: Really hits the spot. The falafels are quite nice - I like that they're available for $0.50 each, although it's a shame there's not a discount the more you buy! The super falafel is a nice sandwich, although I found it odd that I missed the potato in it. Are they tiny chunks, or did I just get unlucky and miss out on them? I would have liked to have had the shwarma but it was pretty disconcerting that the meat was not rotating and the heat didn't seem to be on. The rice and onion looked really good. The employees were also really pleasant.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Recently I've been obsessed with shawerma, chicken and lamb.  I see doner meat on a spit, and I am drawn irresistibly into the premises.  Sunrise has two spits on display by the window, so I found myself waiting in line at the deli counter.  They're really into Yelp.  One of the employees was sporting a People love us on Yelp shirt and they had Yelp cards on the counter.  Cute.

The items in the deli case looked good: hummus, baba ghanouj, tabouli, and some other salads.  There's a shelf of desserts (e.g., baklava) and some grocery items (e.g., canned chickpeas) towards the back.  The grocery item selection is pretty small.  There are half a dozen tables.  

I ordered the chicken shawerma ($5.99).  Good price.  The all white meat chicken pieces were on the larger side (I like my meat in smaller, thinner pieces) but tender and flavorful (marinated with lemon and garlic).  Good tahini sauce. Quite a bit of fresh parsley.  Lettuce, tomatoes.  Everything was very good though the pita bread itself wasn't out of the ordinary (you have to try the pita bread at Rihab's/Good Bites in Belmont to know what really extraordinary flatbread is like).

I tried the Armenian pizza ($2.59), a doughy flatbread topped with ground beef, onions and spices.  It's a bit spicy.  Good topping.  The crust didn't have much chew to it.  It was a bit better toasted but still, I was underwhelmed by the crust.  They bake ring bread on the premises but I haven't tried it yet.
author: Lolia S.

description:
About 8 years ago I lived a block from this place and it was some of the best med food in town.  This is no longer that place.  Apparently the old owner had a tragic accident and had to sell the place.  The new owner just doesn't have the same soul.  The old friendly atmosphere is replaced by a guy who's just running a business.  Too bad too because the old owner and proprietors were really fantastic - got to know me by my second visit and were giving me free oddities to try by my third.  The current place serves basic falafel and shwarma but its mediocre at best.  The other place I knew from this neighborhood, Just Like Home, closed down as well, but I've seen some of the folks who worked there at other establishments, like Tomato Basil on Kearny.

If you want great falafel or shwarma, head just a bit east down Irving to Yumma's at 9th.  

Glad Sunrise is still serving up their fare in outer sunset just to keep the variety, but its really not worth going out of your way.
author: Jack S.

description: Pretty solid. I've tasted a lot of shawermas in SF bay area.  Its not the best, but it will do. Their falafels are pretty good.
author: Demanding T.

description: When it's time for falafel I head to Sunrise.  No frills.  Just delicious crisp on the outside melting on the inside falafels.
author: Ash A.

description:
I would love to rate this the best falafel in the city, but maybe I'm missing something here? Maybe it's only fantastic  Mon - Fri, and on Saturdays at noon?  Maybe it was the rain? In any case, the food was good enough to not feel regretful about eating there. I just had much higher expectations based on what Yelp had said. 3 stars from me with a willingness to upgrade if they prove me wrong next time I go. 

I ordered the regular falafel sandwich. The BF ordered a chicken shawarma and a falafel sandwich (the shawarma portions are a bit small). We were the only diners there. My falafel came out first and it wasn't bad. Pretty standard, actually. Because I sat facing the door, I was able to see them make my BF's chicken shawarma. Not wanting to ruin his dining experience, I didn't mention that they didn't slice the chicken from the turning meat thing (the pit?). Instead, they got the chicken from a different container and heated it up in the oven. Huge disappointment. This would never happen at Truly Mediterranean (our go-to Shawarma spot in the Mission). 

Best falafel in town? I honestly cannot claim that here. Maybe on a different day, at a different time, they actually bring their "A" Game. But for now, the only "A" they get is "A-Ok."
author: Rona J.

description:
Outstanding shawarma!

ask for a few pickled beets and a few olives on the side with your shawarma, the tastes work well together.
author: Brendan R.

description:
Best. Shawarma. in-the-whole-wide-world-not-just-this-world-but-every-world-in-the-entire-universe-plus-infinity!!!

Ok maybe I'm exaggerating, but definitely the best shawarma I've had.  The ingredients are always fresh, every last bit.  

The meat.......hot & fresh.
The hummus.........fresh.
The tomatoes & lettuce......fresh.
The taziki.......fresh.
The pita.......fresh.

What does this all mean?  It's FRESH like I said in my intro.  DUH!!

I might only notice this since I've worked foodservice, but the owners and workers keep the deli and service area impeccably clean & sanitary.  Mr. Clean bows down in their prescence.  Watch them whenever they're fixing your food, they never let the toppings in the deli display drip outside the bowl or god forbid on the rim of the bowl itself.
author: Eric W.

description:
I was heading home after taking my yoga class. I was waiting for the 71 and was hungry and decided since it wasn't coming, I'd head over to this place and finally get me something good to eat.

I stopped in and settled on getting a chicken shawarma sandwich.  I was trying to figure out what a falafel was while I was waiting for my sandwich and asked the guy what exactly a falafel was.  Next thing I know, he handed me a falafel with some hummus on it.  I took a bite and my little taste buds went crazy!!  It was so freakin' good as was the hummus.  Seriously, how can fried food NOT be good, right?  I love any culture that will fry anything and slather some saucy/dip goodness on top.  I said it was good and I said I'd totally be back again.  I was eating while walking down Irving saying out loud, "Oh my gawd, that's good.  It's so good!"  I realized maybe people were thinking i was crazy, but I don't care.  If they had a falafel from there, they'd be talking crazy too.

I got home finally able to eat my sandwich and oh my goodness, it was yummy!!!!!  Salad, hummus, chicken, onions, tomato ... the list goes on.  It was big too!!  I could have eaten half of it, but if I left it, it would have become soggy because of the hummus and pita.

I'm so coming back again.  It's greatly priced and easy hand food if you need to eat on the go.  My pita was $7.04 and it was worth it.  

Get your ass on the bus or in the car and head over for some falafel goodness!!!!!!!
author: imelda j.

description:
Recently had their falafel sandwich in a pita.  The falafel itself was really good, nicely fried and crunchy with an excellent center.  Where the meal fell short was in it's accompaniments.  The hummus was disgustingly runny (who wants runny hummus?...yuck) and the accompaniments (lettuce, pita, etc) were just okay.

All in all, despite that, I thought it was pretty good, especially considering that it's in the sunset.  In my humble opinion, it's not the best falafel sandwich I've ever had and doesn't hold a candle to my favorite in the east bay, but is still a good, solid, and convenient local alternative.  Also, I'm not sure if it's a fair comparison since Sunrise Deli is more of a deli cafe than a real restaurant.

If you're in the area and have a craving for good falafel, it's definitely my first choice (in the sunset).
author: Roy N.

description:
I've been evading writing a review of this place because i didn't want to play a role in a downshifting of such an earnest, unassuming merchant in an area chock full of an entirely different cuisine, but i gotta to admit i've had an all around better falafel in this city. I thought all the figures were in place for an absolute smear campaign of superiority, but even after the fact that its handmade, prepared fresh in front of your eyes, gorgeous, piping hot and hulking in construction, it all came down to a matter of flavor which i think damaged the periscope. With a well rounded falafel, the cascading oils are normally balanced with that taste silencer, but the second directive was incapable of being reached. (Sabra Grill in China town right off bush., best falafel anywhere) The hummus was wholly unremarkable too.  

I still think this place has the colossal cojones to rectify this initial opinion and profess a gloriously unabated victory over the squawking howls of the citywide greek skirmish. Maybe its the fact i've given it the lowest score yet and i give these other raters the benefit of the doubt, maybe its logistics ( how does a med. place prosper on 22nd and irving and not be considered an intrepid legend?) HEY SUNRISE, I KNOW YOU ARE CAPABLE OF TRANSPORTING ME TO TAHINI PARADISO, WHY YOU NO COMPLY!?!?!!?!
author: Christopher J.

description:
This is a case of a place where the owners of the restaurant, are the same ethnicity as the type of food they are serving.  Why this is important?? Authenticity :-)

This place definitely has an authentic feel, whether its their tahini sauce, their shawarmas, and of course their falafels.  Let me tell you, if you like falafel and haven't tried this great little hole in the wall, then you are missing out!  The food here is great and its definitely worth checking out if you are a fan of middle eastern food.

As mentioned before, this place is very cheap, which is always a welcomed bonus when the food is so tasty.  I have been to several middle eastern food establishments where i paid as much as 10.99 for a lamb shawarma and 8.99 for a falafel sandwich.  This place has all of their shawarma sandwiches at 6.99 and their falafel sandwiches for under 6 bucks, which is cheap by relative standards. 

Another great thing about this place is the people behind the counter.  If you choose to eat there, then they bring the food to you, which is kind  of nice for a smaller hole in the wall "fast food" type of place.  Although i think several of the employees did not speak english, they were nonetheless friendly and attentive to our requests.    The owner is a nice guy who you can tell genuinely likes the food that he makes...that may sound silly, but i would argue that you can't say that about alot of places now.  

I am slightly critical of this place, which is why i didnt give it 5 stars.  I will say that with the exception of the falafel, its not the "best" middle eastern food i have tasted.  I have tried a place in palo alto that tastes slightly better in terms of their shawarma and a few other things.  

But the star of this place is no doubt the falafel, so make sure when you stop by, you get a sandwich! Or if you have never tried falafel and are curious if you will like it, this place is for you because you can try individual falafels for only 25 cents :-)
author: Mark R.

description: Came here with a coupon deal -- you know the sites that offer them -- only to find out that this was not a location for the "deal."  SURPRISE!  The gracious employee  at the counter quickly stated that he would still honor the coupon deal -- Talk about making brownie points with the customer!!!   Its businesses like this that make you WANT to patronize them. I don't know much about middle eastern food, but everything on the menu sounded  tasty and looked great. I had the lamb shawarma and some cucumber-tomato salad. Didn't know  what the purple stuff in the sandwich was -- asked and was told it was turnips. I happened to like it.   I was to full to try the falafel!
author: Lorraine M.

description:
"Best Falafel in Town" - not so sure about that claim.  Due to San Francisco's lack of middle eastern food, I have not had much falafel here, but I've had it in Manhattan and Paris, not to mention Greece and Israel, so I'm pretty sure I know what I'm talking about.

The falafel was the best thing I had on my Vegetarian Plate, fried to order, crunchy on the outside yet not greasy, and good flavor.  But the other items on the plate make this only a three-star rating.  The hummus was thin and bland, the tahini was sour tasting, and the mystery item that was dyed pink made the meal mediocre.  The tabouli and baba ganoush (as well as my baklava) tasted like they'd been sitting in the display case for too long, and while the dolmas were good, I'm pretty sure they came out of the giant cans that are for sale in the back.  The pita bread almost certainly came out of a package, and the round bread they're known for was sold out at lunch time so I didn't get to try that.

I'm glad I didn't want to try the Doner Kebab (lamb or chicken), because the contraptions that spin the meat around the heating element weren't spinning.  And the heat wasn't on.  Which makes me skeptical about the quality of that meat.

I'm sure I'll be back for the veggie plate because I crave this type of food and don't know of anywhere else in the neighborhood to go, but there are other places I'm going to explore first.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Driving out to this part of the outer Sunset, where parking can be difficult, and being a pedestrian can be lethal, would seem too much risk involved for the simple act of having some falafel. 

But Sunrise is that good.

For years I've bitched to Arab falafel shop owners that they should incorporate avocado into their sandwiches. Know what? Sunrise has been doing that for years, probably long before my know-it-all-Persian ass had ever even thought of it.

I go for the deluxe falafel and have them add avocado, because I prefer lavash bread to pita, but they'll do it however you want.

Now if only they'd move their base of operations a little closer to civilization.
author: Jason R.

description:
The best falafel in the city. And dirt cheap.  As far as Middle Eastern deli's go it's super authentic. I was totally impressed. They have mamoul, and namura. There is Shawarma (gyros) and a handful of truly Arabic pastries, savory and sweet. And a small handful of useful stuff that you can get pretty cheap. 

I took a star off because the store is big and empty. The deli is great but I'd love to see shelving there with more Middle Eastern grocery. There was one a long time ago that closed down (Almost Home I think it was called) but since it closed down, no one has filled the void. How about some home made Arabic coffee, some rugs and tables and backgammon if you aren't going to use all that space? As I said, the place is cheap.
author: Fareed R.

description:
Falafels, avocado and pita bread. "Those are a few of my favorite things!" 

To die forrrrrr, those avocado falafels and for just $6? Damn thing was filling as hell but everytime I drive by now, I seriously want to stop by and order one of those again. Obsessed.
author: Steph W.

description:
Odd setup, but gets the job done.

Not a TON of seats, but plenty of space... so if you have a group, just rearrange the tables if there aren't many patrons.

Had the lamb and vegetarian shwarma plates; they were good.
A-ok overall price & quality/taste if based on only the plates...but the FALAFELS are what give this place the extra star.

I had one falafel with my dish and decided to add 1/2 dozen even though I was already full. Crispy, warm, sort of like a chicken nugget but WAY better and vegetarian!

Falafels are the tastiest and best deal here!
author: Angel L.

description:
This place seems like a small, cute Mediterranean place. Starving, my girlfriend and I went in and ordered Kufta Kabob and Lamb Shawarma.

Nothing in our experience was particularly good. The service was unfriendly; they barely spoke English and it felt like they really really didn't wanna be there. They screwed up our order and gave us two Lamb Shawarmas; when we asked, the guy clearly said one was a Kufta Kabob, but it clearly had hummus in it (which only the shawarmas do, according to their menu). 

As for the food itself, it was very mediocre. The items were stuffed with veggies and had barely any meat. The tzatziki was bitter and there was nothing special about the pitas. At $7 each, the serving size was below average. 

Water isnt free: you have to buy a bottled water. I hate it when restaurants do that just to milk you for some more money.

Its strange... I'm rarely disappointed with food. Its uncommon for me to dislike a restaurant this much. I have to give this place one star because of unfriendly service, bad food and no real redeeming qualities.
author: Zain M.

description:
Went here on a sleepy foggy Wednesday afternoon for a bite to eat.  In terms of ambiance and rusticness, this place gets 5 stars.  Service, this place gets 5 stars.  Selection and price, this place gets another 5 pentagrams.  They even get the bonus for the interesting and museum-like display of middle eastern grocery items in the back.

Where this place falls a little short is the mortar (hummus) which holds up the foundation (falafel) which this place seems to be most loved for.   The hummus was shiny and too beige...limp.  It needs to have slightly more heft (garbanzos) to it ....and give me some spice while you're at it, baby!  Why should hummus ever be bland?  Don't tell me it's to prevent drowning the flavors of the other things - because they weren't too spicy either!

Baba ganoj was good, falafel was crispy and fresh. Pita bread is actually GOOD here (not dry and an afterthought).  What could improve everything is a little spice!  Cayenne, cumin, what have you...just add something.  

Also, this place is cool because they sell the famous Ring Bread, which if you visit Turkey you cannot avoid.  It looks moister and better at Sunrise, though.  They also have some delicious looking sweets in the counter under the register.

Sunrise, bring me some spice, and I will become a loyal customer in no time!
author: Rachel E.

description: One of the best falafel's in town. For about $3, 6 of these wonderful bite size morsels are a real treat for the senses, crunchy, full of favor and it keeps the taste buds wanting more. Goes very well with some cucumber dip or just  sour cream.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
Was in the area and looking for a place to grab a bite to eat when I came across Sunrise Deli & Cafe.  Sunrise Deli & Cafe is a Mediterranean stop where if you're looking for something that is cheap and good to eat this is your spot.

The place is pretty beat up and they can use a new display case and more variety of Mediterranean Food, but overall this place is very solid.  One of the bonuses here, is they are very cheap, especially in San Francisco.  Looking over the menu (prices for most meals range between $5 for wraps/sandwiches to about $12 for plates) on the board I decided to go with the Falafel Sandwich.

The owner told me to make myself comfortable so I grabbed myself a coke and sat down.  Looks like he was making the Falafel fresh, which is a bonus.  Probably took about 10 minutes, but instead of the normal 1/2 a Pita, I got two BIG Falafel Pita.  Everything tasted fresh and was very good.  I ended up paying around $8 including tip for the Falafel Pita and coke.

Overall very solid food experience.  While not the "Best" Falafel I've ever had, I have to say it was a damn good falafel and at a cheap price too.  Definately would add this to my cheap eats list and would come back again.  Solid 4 star spot and good spot for a Falafel that can feed 2.
author: Chris C.

description:
Until my visit to Sunrise Deli & Cafe, I had never had a falafel. Ever. Yeah, I don't know where I've been either. Anyway, so I'm standing in front of the counter, thinking aloud and asking no one in particular what the hell are falafel's, when the owner takes a falafel and gives it to me. 

I stood there for a good ten seconds, waiting for him to cut me a small piece, but he doesn't, he just gives me the whole damn thing! Sure, falafel's don't cost a lot, but it was still very generous of him. I'm Asian, Asians love free samples. Like my boyfriend says, "...it just tastes better when it's free." So, if you see me coming your way and you want a better Yelp review, give me some free samples. It'll work wonders on my boyfriend too. Just kidding! 

If I wasn't afraid of breaking out (they're breaded and deep fried), I may have ordered a Falafel Plate, but instead, I ordered the Lamb Shawarma. Oh, thank heavens, it was delicious! My boyfriend, however, ordered the Chicken Shawarma and I'll be honest, I didn't like it one bit, because it tasted like curry and I'm not a fan of curry. 

My only complaint about the shawarma is that I had a difficult time getting a good bite of the lettuce, hummus, and tomatoes with the lamb, because everything wasn't mixed very well inside the wrap. I had to take one bite from the left, one bite from the right, and combine everything together in my mouth. Other than that, it was good. Mediterranean food seems pretty light, I didn't feel too stuffed and had room for dessert across the street at Tuttimelon afterwards.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
One of the biggest drawbacks of knowing how a dish is supposed to taste is that you realize it when it tastes wrong.

I had a doctor's appointment at the sort-of-nearby-if-you're-driving UCSF and decided I would branch out and try something new in San Francisco. Looking on Yelp, this place struck my eye. I love shwarma! It's one of the things I miss the most from my years in Israel! Excitedly I headed over to this place, savoring the possibility of finally finding a decent shwarma in the Bay Area.

Parking is, unsurprisingly, scarce. I shunted my car into a TRUCKS ONLY spot by the nearby Walgreen's, deposited my 50 cents into the timer and ran, with an attempt at nonchalance, to the restaurant. 

On walking in, I breathed a sigh of relief since it was pretty much empty. Just one lady in line in front of me, how long could that take, right? Maybe I wouldn't get a ticket after all. As luck would have it, though, the lady appeared to be the worst of all customers to have in front of you--the finicky party planner. "What kind of salad is that?" "Can I have a small container of that? Oh wait, no, I've changed my mind. A big container. No, never mind, I don't want it at all." As she was about to pay, she suddenly noticed the baklava behind her and went into a prolonged discussion with the cashier about which, if any, baklava she should get.

Thankfully after about 10 minutes of this she noticed me and graciously let me pay for my chicken shwarma. Then the guy who had previously been (very dextrously!) deep frying falafel balls proceeded to put it together.

First of all, I was extremely disappointed that he did not cut the meat straight from the spit. There was a spit, and it was turning, so at least I figured the pieces of chicken I got had come from there at some point. Still, that's part of the fun of shwarma. Not this time.

The ingredients were not very well mixed in the shwarma, and the layers were a bit too distinct for what's pretty much a sandwich which you're forced to eat sequentially.

The chicken... didn't taste like chicken. As I was eating, I kept glancing at my shwarma to make sure that I did indeed get chicken. It was kind of bland and almost bready. 

The hummus saved it though. Most of the hummus I've had in the US is kind of a pale approximation of the real thing. This was a bit too liquidy, but tasted just right. The hummus gets the stars.

Still, I would probably try out another place next time.

Oh, and no, I didn't get a ticket. That's pretty much half a star right there.
author: Catherine B.

description:
I checked out this place yesterday and the Super Falafel was amazing.  It's terrific falafel, eggplant, hummus, lettuce, tomatoes and tahini and pepper sauces served in a wrap burrito-style.

Also got the lamb shawarma, which was less good.  The pita was good, as was the sauce, but there were several chunks in the shawarma that were too tough to chew at all.

Orangina is another plus.  Not much of an "atmosphere" or anything.  Staff is tolerable and efficient.
author: Blake C.

description: This is the first time I have been really impressed with falafel in a long time. This place makes outstanding food in a very relaxed environment. Well done.
author: Scott P.

description: I had the falafel plate, and it was JUST as good as the best Mediterranean food I've ever tasted at this other (more fancy & expensive) place (although the hummus wasn't as flavorful). Definitely a place to go to again!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Well, I've tried a LOT of falafels, but this place is THE BEST!!

Why?

The falafels are SO FRESH and TASTY!  Half the time, they usually wind up frying some right on the spot  just for my order.. But no matter what, the falafels here are always FRESH and CRISPY, and NOT sandy, bland and refrigerated like thousands of other so-called Falafel places.

Prices are great too!  Only $3 or so for a DOZEN falafels to take home!
author: Harry W.

description:
The best falafel I have had in my life.  Falafel sandwich is enough for 2.  Turkish delight is good, too.  

They changed ownership a couple of years ago, so their impressive drink selection dwindled to just 1 case.  They replaced their 8 or 9 refridgerators full of drinksk to shelves with middle-eastern dry goods.  

Oh well.
author: Dong T.

description: I cant believe how consistently great this place is.  If only everywhere were so good so much of the time!  I usually get the felafel sandwich with avocado.  It is huge, not expensive and so tasty.  The folks who work here are really nice.  They have hot sauce!
author: Alphonse G.

description:
You can smell the hot falafels cooking from around the block!! 

They are very good, hot and freshly fried. I got a dozen, a bargain at $3.50. I also picked up the cucumber sauce which is also very good. 

This place is conveniently located right next to 22nd & Irving market. I wil be back!
author: Chili B.

description:
This has been one of my favorite stops for a long time.  A few years ago the business was sold and I miss Mike and the rest of the old ownership dearly.  Nevertheless, if your in the area and have a craving for a shawerma, hummus, baba ghanouj or tabouli- this is a good stop.  I still drop by once or twice  a year to get a dozen Falafels.  

No one ever talks about the olives and pickled turnips.  I love the pickled turnips!
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: If you think this place is great, you should have tried it before they switched ownership a few years back. It USED to have the best falafel in the city. Now its your typical mediocre Arab(not Greek) deli. Damn shame how downhill this place has truly become. Its a little sad for those of us who came here for years eating truly great Middle East food. Those of you giving this place 4 or 5 stars would have given it 20 stars if you could not too long ago.
author: David D.

description:
Sometimes we eat falafel and sandwiches here until we could pop, and then we get dozens to take home and eat throughout the week. Oh the fatness.

Wait. Do you not know what a falafel is? Then you are going to die a sad and pathetic wretch. Do not let this happen! Get to Sunrise Deli today and make sure you can die with a smile on your fat face, and grease on your fingers. 

For immortals like myself, who do not fear the spice, be sure to ask for the spicy dipping sauce.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Busy, busy, busy!

Despite the busy atmosphere, the food is really fresh and well-made. The owner is in charge of the cash register, while the young college student workers are working like slaves as the owner barks down each order to them.
author: Ming S.

description:
So happy that my hair salon is just two doors down from this SF institution. 

Sunrise Deli is the fresh-of-the-fresh. You can sit and watch them make fresh, hot falafels. Or, admire the numerous delicacies in the glass case. 

My personal fave: small vegetarian plate with whole wheat pita. You get almil taste of everything: hummus, babaganoush, tahini, domla, pickled turnips, olives, and even a falafel. 

YUM!
author: Misha F.

description:
The best falafel in SF, and really cheap too!  Make sure you eat it right away though because once it sits for a while it's not as crispy.

The side dish of rice-lentils-onions is also tasty.
author: angela n.

description:
I TRIED to go here twice in one day. First, was at 10am, but "Nothing is ready", he tells me. Then I go at 5:07pm..."We're closed" he tells me. 
Bastard guy. 
I'll attempt to patronize this business some other time. Hopefully they earn more stars from me.

***UPDATE***

So I got to make a stop here this past weekend, before dropping my sister off. It was around 3 pm, so they were now "ready" but not yet "closed". 

I ordered the Shish Kabob plate, with the grilled onion & lentil rice & a side order of falafels. The lamb was good, yet a little on the chewy/tough side. I was a little disappointed with the small portions and that they wouldn't let me have the falafels as one of my side dishes, so I had 2 orders of the rice instead and just ordered 2 falafels. The falafels were delicious! But then I had some of my sisters tabouli salad, which I wasn't a whole lot impressed by. 

Overall, this place was so-so...The food was decent but not unforgettable. Knowing me, I'll give this place another try, maybe give the shawarma a chance? I really want to like this place, I really do...
author: Shannon F.

description:
I have nothing to add.  Sunrise has awesome food, and the folks who work there are super-cool.  Check it out.

(One of these days I'm gonna order the "whole stuffed lamb".  I will invite all of you to come over and share.)
author: David P.

description: I always get the Avocado Falafel every time I am here. For $5.99 you get two pitas filled with falafel, avocado, hummus, lettuce, tomatoes and tahini sauce. I always split it with my fiance and it fills us both up. To get full for $3 bucks works with me. Dolma's are also great, not overly oily. Wish I lived closer, I would get falafel here daily.
author: Erin S.

description:
I lived in Israel for 8 years, and (like most Israelis) ate a whole lot of falafel. This is the best falafelI have found in the entire US. Crunchy on the outside, soft and very moist on the inside --just like in the "old country"
The owner comes from East Jerusalem -- no wonder it tases so authentic. Chicken kabobs are great too -- very tender and not dried out. 
The place has zero atmosphere, but the owner is very nice -- really cares about the customers.
author: kevin f.

description:
I was very pleased.  My falafel had great flavor.  My wife was pleased by her Gyro like sandwhich - whatever it was called.  I would definitely go back here if I was in the area.  The food is cheap and good.

The atmosphere is like old deli meets school cafeteria, crossed with a tiny grocery.  I was surprised at how not busy it was at 11:3 on a beautiful weekend day.  From reading their reviews I thought they might be a little more destination, unique experience.  They are not, but I did enjoy their food, and that is why I eat so YAY!
author: Michael B.

description:
The falafels here are the best!  If you're lucky, you can get them when they're fresh out of the fryer.  They're still good the next day; just pop them into the toaster oven for a few minutes at about 250 degrees.

I haven't tried the meat sandwiches, but they smell great!
author: Denise C.

description:
Pros: Decent prices, fast service. The veggie dishes are awesome! Some of the best vegetarian middle eastern food i've had - great falafels. the veggie combo plate as well as the avacado falafel pita are legit. The hummus is decent.

Cons: The meat dishes are average to slightly below average. Thought the chicken and the lamb were a bit on the dry side. 

Overall: Great vegetarian food, mediocre carnivore food. But I'd come back.
author: A I.

description:
I was torn between trying the best falafel in San Francisco for the first time, or having one of my biweekly Vietnamese sandwiches a hundred feet away at Irving Café and Deli. Because it's a Friday, we decided to try something different, so falafel it was!

I must say, I haven't had a LOT of falafel in my day, but I have tried falafel in a couple places on Haight St, etc. this falafel was fresh and delicious. Freshly fried falafel, the cooking oil was relatively clean, it shows that they take care of the oil and keep it nice. I had the Kafta Kebob (ground lamb and herbs) and my girlfriend had the falafel plate. It was all in all a great lunch. The price was also relatively cheap. Under $20 dollars including a drink. Good stuff. I was tempted to get some dessert at the front counter.. but my stomach said "I'm full."
author: Tony W.

description:
A SOLID 4.5 STARS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Have been coming to Sunrise Deli for years!!!!  Stopped in last night after a visit to Ocean Beach and as typical, was not disappoined!!!

I enjoyed my lamb schwerma with relish, my companion had falafel and also enjoyed some rice and this scrumptious bean salad!!

On previous visits, I enjoyed (and recommend)

Combo plate of hummus, falafel, baba ganoush, pita, olives
Kibbeh
Haydari
Kebabs (chicken or lamb)

This place has always delivered with it's quality food/portions/value...but the venue itself was never posh...usually just phoning in an order and either parking illegally or having a co conspirator circle the block while you dash in to collect the goods!!  The odd times I dined in,  I'd find myself  at some random table with a shaky leg (the table, not me)   sitting across from shelves of groceries..."hey,  this stuff looks like Palmolive but it's made in Amman (Jordan)!"  And the owners Mother I think, is there alot, keeping an eye on everyone and especially women who might have carnal desires about her son (hey, maybe being around all those rounds of meat do something to me, I dunno!")   So...imagine my surprise when I saw they had remodeled a bit! It's not Gary Danko's but it's much tidier/better tables and chairs (they match now, well mostly) even added  a few pics!  Overall, it's still a deli/grocery shop/hole in the wall, but thats part of it's charm! And it has never disappointed food wise, so there you go!

The reason i gave the 4.5 stars is because of the parking situation...I mean, it's not the restaurants fault I suppose, but the hit or miss (miss mostly) does influence how much you'd want to get over there and dine in or out!  However, at least with this place, once you get there and experience the yum o food, you're always glad you made the effort!!!

Shoukran, Sunrise Deli!!!
author: Karen S.

description:
General feeling towards falafel --- "Ehhh...why bother?"

Insert the fried-to-a-perfect-golden-brown-crisp, creamy centered falafel, courtesy of Sunrise Deli.

Enlightened attitude towards falafel (and avocado)  --- "Hell to the yes!!"

It's safe to say that as far as falafel goes, the sun rises AND sets with Sunrise Deli.
author: Chelle Y.

description:
Adding another catering review to the mix.

I was organizing a business luncheon for about 60 people and needed a new caterer since we were getting bored of all our usual places. A colleague suggested Sunrise Deli and it turned out to be pretty good!
Based on their suggestions I ordered 5 veggie platters, 6 pounds of chicken, and 6 pounds of kufta kabob. With delivery this was $630. I was worried there wouldn't be enough food, but I was WRONG!
Punctual delivery! The chicken was very well done (my fave) - it was moist and very flavorful. The kufta kabob was more popular than I even anticipated. The falafel was getting somewhat cold by the time I got to it, but it was tasty. The pita tasted like your usual store-bought style...simple and functional.
My only complaint is about the proportions. My group is rather carnivorous and the meat disappeared whereas we had tons of veggie/falafel leftovers. If your group is like mine, order 20% more meat and 20% fewer veggies than what Sunrise Deli suggests. Despite this, nobody left hungry so we will definitely use them again!
author: C S.

description: I absolutely love the falafel here. Whenever I crave a deep fried fix these always do it for me. Inexpensive at 4.99 a dozen you cannot do better price wise. Their freshly made hummus and Babaganoush is always fabulous as is their shawarma platter. My daughter loves the Mujjaddara lentils and rice. Yummy.
author: Sohil P.

description: Although this place is a hole in the wall and doesn't really look like it could produce anything impressive, I love grabbing lunch here after getting my nails down a few doors down. Their falafels are delicious and very very reasonable. The shwarma plates are also very good. Love the hommous and tabouleh too. They have a variety of yummy breads for sale as well as desserts. Take them home with some hommous and babaghanoush and dinner's all set. Only drawback is that they fry up the falafels there in this huge vat of oil and you will definitely smell of it when you leave.
author: Anita L.

description:
my buddy was gonna cut my hair the other day at her house, and we decided to scavenge for food beforehand. we walked down irving and it was like, "asian...asian.... more asian... should i get this asian or that asian? i had this asian last night and i'll probably have that asian tomorrow night so i dunno.." then.. 

TA-DA!! middle eastern food?!? fuck yes. 

we went inside and the place was pretty much dead silent except for homeboy eating there, which i'll get to in a second. anyways they have a big menu poster board thing, and my friend [who has never had middle eastern food] decided she wanted chicken shawarma "because the picture on the poster looks pretty". so i was like yeah, it looks pretty good. i want me some falafels though. we ordered our food and chyea, they're not the friendliest people around but i don't think they were particularly rude. her chicken shawarma and my falafel sammich came out to 16$ and some change. took it home because homeboy there was kinda weirding us out, and if i had to use one word to the describe the food it would be: solid. just solid, yummyness. 

apparently our homeboy agrees with us, because the whole time we were waiting for our food he was SMACKING on his shit. like forreal just.. *smacksmacksmack* *moan* "so good" *smack some more* [seriously guys. i can't make this shit up]. at one point he came up for air and told the guys behind the counter, "it's soooo good. everytime i come. so gooood. *smacksmack*"

so hey. take his word for it, yadigg?
author: Angela L.

description: Delicious and cheap. Don't go for the decor or location (Spartan interior), go the tasty, fresh food.
author: Martin O.

description: Don't order the catering platters. They rip you off. The meat platter consisted of 25% meat and 75% sliced onions. The vegetable platter was supposed to come with 2 bags of pita bread and 2 dozen falafels. he only gave me 1 bag and 1 dozen falafels. I question him and he insisted. At least change the menu. Just lost a customer.  I'll stick to Truly Meditteranean on 16th and Valencia.
author: j l.

description: You've heard about these guys, now go try their falafel. I've had "great" falafels in NY, and dude, Sunrise takes the cake. See for yourself.
author: Rich B.

description:
Sunrise, sunset
Sunrise, sunset

I had a lamb gyro here once.  It was about $8.  It was just ok.  I was watching someone else order their food and they got a super shawarma.  It looked big and good.  Next time I decide to stop in I am going to order this.  I am also curious to see how the scored on their health inspection.  Looks dirty but more dirty equals more flavors.  YummA!
author: Fatty A.

description:
Sunrise serves some BOMB-ass falafels. These little falafel balls are so fresh, flavorful, and delicious. They come out so warm and crispy on the outside, yet so moist and soft on the inside. Droooools. At a couple of bucks a pop, they are the perfect snack. I have yet to try their sandwiches and other plates, but if they are anything like the falafels, I am definitely missing out. 

Check em out, Sunrise will not disappoint.
author: Phoi B.

description: One of just a few mediterranean places I think is best. I was introduced to this kind of food (here)  when I was a kid. Simply 1 of 2 places I recommend in San Francisco.
author: Cup C.

description:
Falafel: the best you can have in N. America
Falafel sandwich: average
Lamb Shawarma sandwich: nothing special. Hummus doesn't go with a shawarma sandwich. 
Hummus: absolutely horrible. It's more like hummus soup. Keep hummus away from y our sandwich. Can't understand this one, if you can make great falafel can't you even buy good hummus. 
Dolma: average
author: Ifred M.

description: The food was good enough, but wasn't great.  The staff was nice.  I'd be back if I wanted to stay close to home for Mediterranean but given my druthers I'd go someplace else.
author: Alan S.

description: I go to their Berkeley location and its the best falafel around.  So fresh and tasty.  Their food is inexpensive, feeds a crowd, and really tasty.   Not a fancy spot - but great for take out.
author: Madhuri K.

description: I looooove love love Sunrise Deli. AMAZING FALAFEL. Sooo good. Really good yogurt dip and hummus too. The owner of the place is hella nice - I wanted to try a falafel and they just gave one to me, even though it's like $2.50 or something for one. Definitely one of my favorites in Sunset!
author: Christine A.

description: Best falafel I've had outside of the Middle East!
author: Eyal C.

description: I've ordered take-outs from here a few times as we love to switch things up every once in a while and I've been happy with what we brought home. However we decided to eat there one sunny day after doing some grocery shopping at 22nd Market. Their falafels are definitely the bomb but they tasted even better fresh off the frying pan! Crispy on the outside soft and just tasty on the inside. I usually stuffed them in the pita with chicken and hummus and their cucumber salad. Delish!
author: Sara M.

description:
Sunrise has been in my hood for 20 years and i have NEVER been disappointed - their party trays (which i have used for everything from my son's Baptism to my birthday party) are uniformly fabulous - and folks always ask - where is this (fabulous food) from?
best shwarma, best falafel  - and frankly the best peeps -a wonderful family with consistently good stuff .   go THERE if you are hungry.
author: Artemis C.

description: These falafels are the best in the city.  They're crispy and delicious and just flavorful.  Their lamb wrap is also pretty good.  The service is not that fastest ever, but the people that work there are really nice.  Overall, it's a nice place for a fast bite.
author: Praise C.

description:
5 stars JUST for their falafel. 
My family has been coming here for years!
We love to cut up the falafel and put those scrumptious morsels into our Burmese soups. OMG THE BEST. 

After a long day of Asian grocery shopping, dropping off mail at the Post Office, fresh, hot falafels are the perfect snack. Warm, a tinge of spice, and tons of garbanzo been goodness.
author: Christine C.

description: AMAZING! i loved this place. i stopped by on accident after Walgreens and I got the falafel plate. It was delicious! the place isn't one where you'd like to stay, but for take out or on the run its great, and either way the food is fresh and delicious. I didnt mind waiting a while for them to make the falafel, because it was delicious with all the right sauces and pita, all the works.
author: Nikita K.

description: I would never go back here. The falafel is cooked perfectly, but lacks any flavor whatsoever and sits in a case getting stale all day. The hummus has the after-taste of a chlorine pool. The woman putting the food together used her ungloved fingers to handle all of the food. The place is dirty and the food is not fresh. I didn't even like the hummus -- and that is a first for me.
author: El C.

description: Sunrise has the best falafel, ever. Really. I've eaten lots of falafel, in many different cities and countries, and Sunrise really knows how to make falafel. Each ball is light and airy, not at all greasy, but also very flavorful. I love it. I really can't say enough about how delicious their falafel is. The customer service is eh, okay -- it's not the friendliest place in the world, but who cares? The food's amazing!
author: Lauren L.

description:
I've heard great things about this place from co-workers who are native SF residents.  They swear it's the best falafel in town.  Well, a couple weeks back, my boyfriend decided to forgo a 45 min. trip into the Mission from our house by the beach and man, were we satisfied!  I had the falafel with avocado, while my boyfriend had the large falafel.  After ordering our food, it was served to us no more than 5 minutes later.  We just dove into our meals and honestly, I have never had a more juicy and flavorful falafel sandwich.  True, it was a little messy; there was tzatziki sauce dripping all over my fingers but it was so worth it!  Then, to finish off your meal, take a look at all the fine pastries they have sitting behind the counter and don't limit yourself to the baklava, since they have other items as well. 

This is a place definitely worth checking out for those of you who are convinced there are no good falafels west of 19th avenue.
author: Christine S.

description:
Wow. W-O-W....their falafel sandwich takes on all comers, and does so with one hand tied behind their  back (in order to make more tahini perhaps...)

in any case, i've been going for over a year, and their falafels are amazing- yummy crispy on the outside, and soft and de-lish on the inside....

plus the chicken schwarma is stunning too... and always seems to win the lunch tug of war...in any case, if you're looking for the best falafel- heres the place
author: Tim V.

description:
The falafels here are so good they have become a staple in my weekly meals. At least once a week I drop by and get a dozen of falafels, half a dozen of really fresh and good dolmas as well as their sesame bread - and what I like to do is cut the bread in half add some feta, tahini and falafel and there you have it. Excellent. Try it at your house!
I give them 4 stars as I have not tried any of their other stuff really - the falafels are so good, this is what I want to be having every time.
author: Chris D.

description:
I have only been in this section of the sunset for a lil while, but sumbitch this place is killer!
They make a super falafel that is the size of a burrito which will knock your socks off. Their hummus is creamy and incredibly flavorful. The dolma....well I always get half a dozen, even if I have already ordered 3 items.
I think they do catering as well, but I have yet to experience it.
The lamb shawarma is the shwizzle (yeah, I will probably edit that one) and I still can't get over the hummus...shit, I will be there tonight around 5....see you there :)
author: Nic K.

description:
A quick falafel run, this place does it. Nothing to brag about... 

The cucumber & yogurt salad was a bit too tart for me.
author: Anna S.

description:
I also ordered a lamb shawarma, which was hot and juicy. The wait for the schwarma took a while, but I say it was worth the wait. I didn't have enough cash when I paid for my shawarma (stupidity on my part), but they do take credit cards. However, there's a $10 minimum purchase, so that's where I ordered half a dozen falafels to hit the $10 mark. It was my first taste of falafel and I thought it was good, but not when eaten in large amounts. 

Overall, I thought it was a good place to eat, but it can be a little over-price.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place. I wanted some lunch one day so I finally stepped in.
I ordered the Falafel plate and I was full and satisfied!
The boss guy seemed pretty nice and they were so fast. I barely sat down but my food was already ready.
I will come back next time and try something new too!
author: Shu L.

description:
This is where Arabs go to get Arabic food.

It really doesn't get any better than Sunrise Deli if you're looking for authentic Arabic food in the Bay Area. I've been coming here since I was a kid, and the food tastes the same today as it did 15 years ago. Family owned and operated and the recipes come from and old Arab lady, so you know they're good.

I highly recommend the lamb shawarma w/ hummus plate, a dozen falafel, and ring bread w/ tons of their tahini salad.
author: Kal N.

description: The best Falafel i have ever had in the bay area.  Outside of Palestine it is the best Falafel fresh always hot, you can call make orders.   I always go but fresh falafel for my family take a couple of dozen home.  What ever I have left I always freeze in bags of 12 then for breakfast I take them out and put in my toaster oven and heat.  They always taste great.  I give thanks to the new owners who never changed the ingredients.  My friend owned this shop.  Salwa El kharsa and Naima.  God Bless them where ever they are.  Bringing the Palesitnian Dish to our hearts and homes....
author: Linda M.

description: O man, love the falafels.  I haven't tried anything else yet, but you bet I will!  I hope falafels aren't toooo fattening, I know they're deep fried.. don't wanna think about it.  I'll update my review as I try the other foods... I'm excited!
author: Alice E.

description:
Want some good wholesome falafel (or as we Egyptians call it, 'taamiya')? Go to Sunrise Deli!! Even with the management change, they haven't changed the recipes which is good for me!

Have a falafel sandwich with the cucumber yogurt, it's the best! It's also awesome to get platter's done with a dozen falafel, hummus, cucumber yogurt and pita... feels like back home without the fava beans.
author: Ms. Hala A.

description: I have been a Sunrise Deli falafel fan for more years than I care to admit.  Through two owners, the food here is delicious enough to deal with the parking mess on Irving.  It's a bonus if the Pita bread is still warm. If you have an event, try the vegetarian party platter, it is plenty of food for 8-10 (women).  My Marin Bocce team loves it at least once a season.
author: Cali M.

description:
The falafels these guys whip up are the best.  The gyros are pretty good too, but the falafels are too perfect to pass on so I usually get the plate, super, regular or avocado falafels.  Another plus is my pita never cracks open or leaks because it is dried out.

The interior is definitely nothing special, but it is clean and does not damper the appetite.  The dudes working there are always pretty nice, patient and chill.
author: Violet S.

description:
Great food -period.
Service is fair-to-midland. I personally  don't like seeing and listening  their drama while they work.  It really wouldn't matter except that it seems to impede the time of the food preparation, and the accuracy of what you order...and it happens nearly every time I go in there it seems.
Overall a good experience.
author: Rick H.

description:
Being in the neighborhood around dinner time, we figured we'd stop and get some cheap fast chinese food from one of the gajillion places in mini-chinatown #43.  But then, lo and behold, we came across Sunrise Deli which, for whatever reason, had never caught our eye.  As a falafel connoisseur, I was actually excited to see what they had to offer.  After partaking in the Super Falafel and the Falafel plate, I have to say that the falafel is pretty damn good.  I still prefer the Falafel Deluxe at Yummas (tastier veggies and more grilled), but Sunrise Deli is a close second.  On the other hand, it's closer to our house and easier in terms of parking, so we might end up here more often than Yummas.

Otherwise, service was good, everything seemed clean and organized and the prices were fair.  All in all, a solid 4 stars.
author: Jason W.

description:
This place has the BEST kibbeh, and THE BEST falafel sandwich in San Francisco! Their parsley tahini salad is great too, and so is their hummus! 

I love their warbat and their hareeseh.

Sunrise's Shawerma is good, but I prefer Yumma's!
author: Maddy S.

description: Falafel!  I have had great and not so great falafel, but this place is so good!  I loved the falafel plate.  Also had some baklava which was equally delicious.  When we were about to leave, we spotted some bread and got it go.  I could not believe how incredible this bread was!  Freshly baked, warm, topped with seasame seeds.  So delicious.
author: Shawn Y.

description: By far the best falafel in the city, just trust me. Super fresh and crunchy. Their kubeh is also super tasty when available, taste like a dominican quipe! They have a second location on 2nd and market.
author: Adriani L.

description:
I use to think that this was my favorite place for falafel, but after exploring and eating at other falafel joints outside of San Francisco, i'm sorry to say that this place does not have the best falafels. But still, its a good size, tasty, crispy on the outside, fresh, and cheap.

The baba ghanouj is a bit too lemony, but if you are a lover of lemons, go for it. It still has a nice consistency.

room for seating, friendly people at the counter, parking could be tough...good time to get lucky

Try Falafel's Drive In in San Jose or Falafel, etc in Fremont for better tasting falafel. Yes, they're smaller in size, but they taste better there. You just have to try it for yourself if you happen to be in the area.

Overall, i'd come back here IF I were in the area and craving some falafel.
author: Veronica H.

description:
I've very rarely had falafels and wondered what people here were talking about, so I tried a couple and they were pretty good. Yes, crispy covering but on the downside, it's oily. Which I happen to like when I'm not on a diet.
I had the shawarma and it wasn't a roll like I had hoped, but it was awesome nontheless. The olives/pickles on the side go well with the dish.
Owner was attentive and the place had a feel of down-to-earthness.

Stop here for a quick lunch in your shorts and hawaiians, or get a take-out, but don't take your date here =)

Oh, parking is impossible in this area.
author: Eyw d.

description: Great falafel shawarma!  Stopped by this place randomly, and was pleasantly surprised.  Looking at this place from the street, it doesn't seem like much, but once you enter, and have those fried to order falafel, it's over!  Hands down the best falafel I've had in the city.  We also ordered a few other things, but they werent that memorable.  If you're in the sunset, and looking for some great falafel, stop by this place and order away, although keep your eyes peeled, this place is small, and you can easily pass it up.
author: David M.

description: Very good food . The only thing i had is the super falafel. Wait was very short. I will be back to try more things on the menu.
author: Emily G.

description: I'm not a huge falafel fan, but this is the place for the real thing.  I think this is a more Palestinian or lebanese style eatery.  The schwarma is just juicy enough without be too greasy.  But the best thing here might be their salads and appetizers.  There's some sort of great herbed tahini sauce that tastes good on anything here.  I once had Foul Madamas here (fava beans) that were the most satisfyingly garlicky beans I've ever had.  This breakfast dish takes 24 hours to cook right and few places will offer it this side of the bosporus.  The Berkeley Sunrise deli is not nearly as good, but worth a try. Best affordable middle eastern food in the bay, with a close runner up being Oasis Food Market in Uptown Oakland.
author: Peter B.

description:
Admittedly, I haven't compared and contrasted all of the Mediterranean places in town, but I gotta say....this place has some of the best Falafel and Hummus that I have EVER had.  The Falafel has just the right texture and crunch on the outside and the Hummus is incredibly smooth and flavorful.

I've been in the neighborhood for over 11 years, and this place has always been consistent quality and service.  The folks behind the counter make fantastic sandwiches and are always super nice.

I've heard some comments about hours, but they always seem to be open when I go during the day.  Definitely worth the stop, and great for take out to go the Park.
author: Heather W.

description: falafel is the best, all of the stuff ive had has been so good. i try to come here at least once a month.
author: Jake C.

description: The falafels here are the BEST I have ever eaten! They're oh so crispy on the outside and soft on the inside and not too greasy.  Plus, they're a dozen for only  $5 or one for $0.50 - you can't wrong with that. I plan to go back to try the Super Falafel sandwich which comes with eggplant and all that other good stuff. Minus one star cuz it's kinda grimy on the inside.
author: Richard C.

description: I am now starting to eat them as the balls themselves. Soooo good! But be warned! They need to eaten when either warm or hot. When they get cold and left in the bag, they leak out their greasy goodness and become not soo good. And not too crunchy, too. So don't say I didn't warn you!!!
author: Anthony L.

description:
I love this place.  Falafel here is amazing, especially when it's fresh out of the frier, which is most of the time.

The guy (the owner?) at the cash register is a total character, too....
author: Lanie W.

description: Great falafel. Both this one and the one near Mission.
author: Shawn B.

description: Was super psyched to come up their food truck at Soma StrEat Food Park.  Thumbs down! Total unprofessional service - love it when the girl taking your order cops an attitude.  Regardless, being hungry I ordered the Super Falafel.  Shocker when I opened it and it had everything but the potatoes so in essence I could have ordered their Regular Falafel and saved myself a few bucks.  Go spend your money elsewhere.  Their food truck is so overrated.
author: Katee D.

description: Their avocado falafel is to me what a hit of the rock must be to a crack head.  I don't even eat it when it hits the table, I attack it!  And sometimes I go back for seconds.
author: eric f.

description:
OMG THE FALAFEL ARE SO GOOD..... MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM


that's all i have to say....
author: Rich V.

description: I simply love this place.  That's all I have to say, but you might want to know why.  This place boasts the best falafels in the city.  I got a dozen to try out and man did they make a good impression on me. I have had "fresh" falafels from other places and theirs were not as flavorful. I also love their falafel sandwich and lamb shawarma sandwiches.  Will come here again.  Cheap too for the portions.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
So I went to the Gay Bay last weekend to my best friend whom I haven't seen in nearly five years. She lives in Sunset amongst a bunch of Chinese folks and shops along Irving. When I got into Sunset, after a flight on Virgin America that left me starving and wanting to eat my left foot, I walked up and down the street trying to decide if I wanted Chinese, Thai, Vietnamese, or what. I first stopped at a grocery store and got some wasabi roasted peas. Then I proceeded to buy frozen yogurt with fruit toppings at some fro-yo shop. But since I like to finish any meal--haphazard or not--with something salty or savory, I popped into Sunrise because I love falafel like I love being a lonely sonofabitch--which is a lot!

It was down to two choices: the Super Falafel or the Avocado Falafel. The avocado falafel promised avocado, hummus, lettuce, tomato, and tahini in a pita. Sounded pretty standard except for the avocado, which in principle, guaranteed a yummy sandwich. However, my interested was more peaked by the Super Falafel - with hummus, eggplant, potatoes, lettuce, tomatoes, and tahini served in a "Lavish Bread." Since I didn't know what the fuck a lavish bread was and the promise of potatoes and savory eggplant in my falafel was too tempting to resist, I order a Super Falafel. 

As I caught a glimpse of the obviously new Mexican employee make my sandwich, I noticed that potato element was french fries. I wouldn't call this a native ingredient in the Near East either, but was loving where this was all going. I looked away and moments later, my sandwich was before me with a small side of pickled turnips and olives. What was first noticeable was that it wasn't so much a sandwich than a Middle Eastern burrito. Apparently a lavish bread is a very flat bread that you can roll up ingredients into for an easy-to-go snack or meal. No wonder why they hired a Mexican for this job!

The premise of this sandwich is excellent, however, the execution doesn't live up to its potential. First, the falafel balls were room were kind of cold and mushy--though it could have been the fault of the tahini. But because the falafel balls were obviously not taken fresh from the fryer, it lacked a crunchy texture that I really enjoy. Next were the french fries--also cold and with no texture. And finally, it took a few bites to finally get  a taste of the eggplant, which didn't contribute enough flavor to the tasting experience. The eggplant could have had some spice, perhaps enhanced in the same delicious way the guys at the falafel cart on 40th and Broadway do it. That would have given the Super Falafel some more dimension. Also, if the falafel balls were hot and the french fries inside more crispy, the sandwich could really live up to its name. But at this point, it is more like "Decent Falafel."

The joint claims to have the best falafel in town. I hope that isn't true.
author: Daniel L.

description: I crave the falafel sandwiches and falafel platter served at this hole in the wall deli. The chicken kabob sandwich is great, but I can't get enough of the falafel. The hummus is so tastey and tangy, I may have go out and get me some right now. and I love the almond halvah.
author: Shannon r.

description: Very good falafel!  Each time I have been there they are freshly made.  I would have given an extra star except the service is a little bit to be desired.  A few of occasions the person calculating the bill rang up the wrong order.  Both times he was on the phone and he ignored what we told him we had.  It was only when we showed him he changed it and no sorry!  He just kept carrying on with his conversation.  But did I say the falafel was very good?
author: D M.
